title: When Did The Remix Become A Requirement?
content: When Did The Remix Become A Requirement?The AwlBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 24, 2012by Mike BarthelConsider this: according to Discogs.com, about 800 remixes were released in 1983. In 1990, more than 4,000; in 2000, almost 15,000. And in 2010, there were 22,750 remixes released, an increase of more than 450% in twenty years. Not surprisingly, as that number has leapt up, remixes also have come to represent a much larger share of what’s being released: in 1983, they accounted for 2% of all releases; 7% in 1990; 17% in 2000; until, by 2010, a staggering 20% of all releases were remixes.How did we get to the point where a one-hit-wonder band from the ’90s like Marcy Playground can release an entire album of remixes made by fans? Why is everyone a DJ these days, and why does every band in the world have to have a remix? The short answer is “because they can.” As technology has advanced, so has the remix. It started in Jamaica in the ’60s with dub effects, emerged in America through disco and the 12" mix, helped to create rap through the power of their sound systems, exploded in the ’90s with the maxi-CD, and became participatory (and ubiquitous) with digital mashups. At each step of the way, the particular kind of technology available shaped the nature of that moment’s remixes.VERSIONING SOUNDUsed as a verb, “remixing” has been possible (and practiced) ever since the existence of multi-track recording. At the dawn of sound recording, a song had to be recorded directly to the form it would eventually be heard, and there was no way of extracting just the bass or guitar part without taking all the other parts with it. But once sound could be recorded to 4 or more tracks (from which it’s then “mixed down” into the final, combined form you hear), engineers could return to the working versions of songs and “remix” them: make the guitar louder, take out all of the vocals, even make the track shorter or longer.This isn’t to say that recorded sound couldn’t be manipulated prior to the advent of multi-tracking. Most notable here is William Burroughs’ “cut-up” technique, which took a Dadaist trick of cutting up words to rearrange text and then applied it to the magnetic tape on which recordings used to reside. Musicians like Brian Eno and Genesis P-Orridge used the technique to clip sections, rearrange them and place them in a new sequence — Burroughs characterized this as a “method for altering reality.” Recording engineers did this too, but they called it an “edit,” and they used it not to alter reality, but as a way to, for instance, shorten a long track for radio play by removing an instrumental section or extra verse.As a noun, though, “remix” implies something a little different than either re-balancing a song or re-arranging its parts. Its use connotes a track that has been fundamentally transformed, either in form or content, into something new. There’s a self-consciousness about remixes: while a radio edit is intended to make the same musical experience available in a different context, a remix is intended to be a new musical experience entirely.As such, the first recordings that could be called “remixes” were produced in Jamaica in the 1960s. The island’s extremely strong local music culture enabled a tight interplay between the people who made records and the people who listened and danced to them. As DJ/producers like Lee “Scratch” Perry saw that crowds were interested in longer musical experiences than they could provide with the single format (the 7" vinyl disc on which singles came was generally only able to hold four minutes’ worth of music without suffering a drop in sound quality), they produced new versions which they referred to as “versions.” What makes these remixes is that, besides dropping out the vocals to concentrate on instrumental sections, producers started adding new material to better capture the energy dancers were looking for, both in the form of new instrumental parts and effects (like long echoes) put on the existing parts.There were economic factors, too. Since Jamaican producers tended to be owner-operators, both recording and distributing their own music, they had access to the multi-track masters at a time when American musicians didn’t. In the United States (and other industrialized countries), the master recordings were owned by the record company, making it much more difficult for artists to get their hands on their own recordings, let alone legally release remixes. With ownership resting on the business side, there was an impetus to see recordings as “finished” for American musicians that didn’t necessarily exist for these Jamaican producers. And since recording equipment was enormously expensive and generally only available in commercial studios where artists would have to pay for time, American musicians simply weren’t able to remix their material in the way people like King Tubby could.WE CATCH ’EM ON THE FLIPThe remix wouldn’t have happened in America without the 12" single. Though the form predates disco, that was the sound that made the remix what we know today. “New York remixers — many of them DJs — weren’t really influenced by Jamaica, in part because New York dance crowds demanded music that was much more up-tempo than reggae and dub,” wrote Tim Lawrence, author of Love Saves the Day: American Dance Music Culture, 1970–1979, in an email interview with me.“Jamaican remixes usually involved the producer-DJs taking out elements from the original track and placing greater emphasis on the drums and the bass via a process of subtraction, but the records weren’t extended. New York remixers would also strip records down, but they were also focused on drama and an idea of a journey, so they would often retain complete elements from the original and would then take the record ‘somewhere else’ by stripping out certain sections and extending others. New Yorkers developed their own remix technique in almost complete isolation and apparently without outside influence for something like seven years.”The first American remixer, it’s generally agreed, is a guy named Tom Moulton, about whom Lawrence writes about extensively in his book. Moulton was interested in finding ways to provide different party experiences to New Yorkers, and experimented with a lot of different techniques, including cutting up existing recordings, as people had been doing for years. Lawrence identifies the first of these as a remix of Don Downing’s “Dreamworld,” which Moulton produced in 1974. Moulton’s signal innovation, though, was to put such remixes on a 12" disc, the format usually used for full albums.In preparing his remix of Al Downing’s “I’ll Be Holding On,” which took a three-minute soul song and extended it to almost seven minutes long, “Moulton’s assistant happened to press up on a 12” blank because he’d run out of 7"s,” writes Lawrence. “Moulton was stunned to hear the power of hearing the music’s grooves spread out over the larger disc.” (Without getting too technical, the less time you’re trying to fit onto a disc, the louder it can be.) The success of this technique led to the first commercially released remix, Double Exposure’s “Ten Percent,” in 1976.While these were a hit with dancers and DJs, labels didn’t feel the same way. As Lawrence put it in his email: “The dance market turned out to have quite different values, with dancers much more interested in hearing a brilliantly re-structured twelve-inch single than listening to a bunch of catchy singles plus extra cuts on an album. That meant that twelve-inch singles didn’t necessarily translate into album sales, and from that point on the music industry (and especially the music majors) were always skeptical of the format.”TAKES YOU BACK TO THE PASTNevertheless, the form persisted in a new genre: hip hop. Jamaican ideas of remixing formed the foundations of the genre, and the initial impetus for rap was very similar to that of dub and disco remixes: Dancers wanted more instrumental sections to dance to and less singing. But with hip hop, MCs picked up the talkover mic and started to add their own vocals. And with parties often happening outside established clubs in outdoor or otherwise improvised spaces, DJs like Kool Herc gained influence as much for the power of their sound systems as their DJing skills. Disco remixes happened because their vinyl was louder; rap happened, in some small part, because DJs’ speakers were louder, making loud vocals an attraction party promoters could provide.At first, hip hop remixes followed a similar pattern to the disco remix, with the instrumental portion of the song altered while the vocals were either cut up or left intact. In an email, Andrew Nosnitsky, who writes about rap for a bunch of different places including The Wire, told me there were good economic reasons for this. “If a record wasn’t connecting at radio they’d give it a different beat and try again. If it wasn’t hitting on the West Coast, they’d get a Warren G remix, if underground mix shows weren’t playing it they’d get it a Beatminerz mix, if they wanted to expand to dance markets they’d push a CJ Mackintosh hip house mix.”But that didn’t last. According to Nosnitsky: “The old model remix, the one where the beat actually changes in some way, has pretty much been dead on an official level for a long time. Nowadays ‘remix’ just means that a gang of famous artists pile verses up on an existing hit.” This is the format we know and love today.EVERYTHING’S REAL IN THE FIELDBut how did remixes end up conquering rock, too? The answer can be summed up in two made-up words: “electronica” and “maxi-single.”The shift from cassettes to CDs put the single in an awkward situation. It was considerably cheaper to produce a vinyl disc or cassette with less information on it, and so a single with an a-side song and a b-side song worked logically with the format. CDs, though, cost the same amount to produce whether they contained 80 minutes or 80 seconds of music. (The mini CD, which functioned in the same way a 7" record would, never caught on.) At this point, it became almost irresistible to start putting more and more tracks on CD singles. If the label could provide more songs with relatively little additional production cost, then they could justify charging more for the CDs. And thus was the “maxi-single” born.What to put on those maxi-singles, though — especially when the whole idea was not to increase the production cost? Bands always produce more songs than fit on an album, but if a label was interested in producing, say, eight different singles for one song, you’d need more than the two or three cast-offs a typical recording session would produce. The answer was remixes. Compared to a whole new recording session, they were cheap to commission, especially if you went with lesser-known producers; the remixers would be flattered to be associated with generally better-known acts; and the artist would benefit from the increased visibility with the remixer’s fanbase. Throw a few of those together — especially if the remixer was kind enough to produce multiple mixes — and you had enough tracks to plausibly fill out enough maxi-singles to bilk a dedicated fan out of at least a hundred dollars. The result was that remixes, instead of being initiated by a producer drawn to a particular track, were getting done whether or not they were a good idea, just to say that such a remix existed. An apocryphal story has it that a courier arrived to pick up a commissioned remix from Richard D. James of Aphex Twin fame, and James, having forgotten to do it, simply grabbed a random track off of his shelf. He got $5,000, and the Lemonheads, the victimized band, never released the mix.But why dance remixes? The traditional filler material for rock bands, after all, was the live album, and indeed live versions of existing songs sometimes ended up on maxi-singles too. At the time, though, there was something much cooler about electronic music. In a historical context, this was unusual; rock bands had for many years defined themselves in opposition to the aesthetics and techniques of dance music. While there were certainly notable exceptions, the idea of rock bands en masse deciding that a dance remix was just the sort of thing they were looking for seemed unlikely. Rock and dance had lined up in the UK in the early ’90s, generating some important work. This had carried forward into Britpop’s more rock-oriented moment (though some were later to the party than others). When the semi-terrifying “electronica” trend hit the US, it coincided with the heyday of the maxi-single, and the two proved well suited to one another.AUDIO PIRACY AS COMPOSITIONAL PREROGATIVEAs with remixes, mashups can be traced back a long ways. John Oswald has been producing what he calls “plunderphonics” for fifty years, the KLF had a number-one hit with their mashup of Gary Glitter’s “Rock and Roll (Part Two)” and the Doctor Who theme song, and the Evolution Control Committee had a few hits on college radio in the early ’90s with their combination of the Tijuana Brass and Public Enemy. Even Malcolm McLaren had a go at it with his haunting (really!) mashup of Joy Division and the Captain and Tennille, “Love Will.” As Oswald put it (in 1988), the practice of taking “a recognizable sonic quote” from an existing song and placing it over something else in such a way that “you can reasonably recognize the source” has cropped up here and there for a long while.As the practice we know today, though, mashups weren’t possible without the technological convergence of high-speed Internet, wide availability of digital music (the so-called “celestial jukebox”), and low-cost audio production software. They’re generally understood to have broken wide in 2001 with “A Stroke of Genie-us,” a track by Freelance Hellraiser combining Christina Aguilera’s “Genie in a Bottle” and the Strokes’ “Hard to Explain.” (The track was the #26 single on the year-end Pazz and Jop critics’ poll.)While prominent mashup artists have emerged (Soulwax, Osymyso, Go Home Productions, DJ Earworm and, most famously, Girl Talk), as a genre it’s highly participatory, encouraging listeners to make their own mashups as much as to consume those already existing. The whole spectrum of tools now standard on any home computer enables this: a CD-ROM drive for ripping music, music recording software for editing music, and a high-speed Internet connection for finding a cappella or instrumental versions of tracks, as well as for distributing your completed work. Most important was the development of the software that let you match the beat of samples, so that even if two songs were in different tempos, you could automatically align them at the same rate without changing the pitch — a process that can take hours to do by hand.It was this same bundle of tools that lands us squarely where we are today. As the entire music market moved inexorably downward, remixes stopped being just about major acts commissioning major remixers; now any band can get its songs remixed, and anyone can be a remixer (I’ve done ‘em). While the physical reality of doing a remix used to involve the cumbersome process of getting the tracks to the remixer and the remixer having the studio space to do the edits, now people who’ve never met can send each other zip files via Dropbox and everything can be accomplished on laptops.The weird thing is that there hasn’t exactly been a renaissance of remixes: while opening up the floodgates to cultural production has produced a few golden ages, this area has ended up looking more like a vast, cluttered wasteland. While there have been lots of great remixes of late, they’ve all been from people with major careers already: the DFA, Jaques Lu Cont, Jamie xx. Remixes have now gotten much easier to do, but they haven’t necessarily gotten better; listening to Moulton’s “I’ll Be Holding On,” it’s hard to say anyone’s done much better.Remixing as a theoretical idea has had a lot of interesting consequences. But remixing as a musical technique has, weirdly, gone almost nowhere at all: it started great and stayed great but never altered itself much along the way. Perhaps because it’s only been around a handful of decades, and that isn’t enough time to ask for such dramatic twists and turns. But the story of remixing seems more or less to be the same story over and over again, retold every time the technology shifts.Sponsored posts are purely editorial content that we are pleased to have presented by a participating sponsor, advertisers do not produce the content. This post is coming to you from MiO. Change your water. Change your day. What do you want to change?Mike Barthel has a Tumblr. Photo by Maxim Blinkov, via Shutterstock.

title: Planning Better Public Transit In Upstate New York
content: Planning Better Public Transit In Upstate New YorkRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 21, 2016Compact, walkable towns, low-density suburbs, and ranges of rural land compose the Capital District Transportation Authority’s service area, from Albany to Schenectady to Troy — all neatly arranged about 15 miles from each other, with Saratoga some 25 miles further north. CDTA’s fixed-route service through upstate New York is an interconnector, and the agency has used Remix to evaluate service changes and restructure routes.Chad Heid, CDTA’s manager of scheduling, is heading up efforts concentrated around Saratoga Springs, which is connected to Schenectady by one well-used line, Route #50. As with any quality route restructuring process, he’s assessing where service currently meets demand and where it’s falling short of the agency’s expectations for productivity, as well as riders’ expectations for travel times, frequencies, and coverage. Remix’s demographic layers have helped him explain to riders how CDTA makes its decisions.We’ve found Remix to be really productive for our purposes in using all the mapping layers, because people will make comparisons about neighborhoods and we’re able to pull up the data with Remix much more efficiently than without the program.“Saratoga is a smaller community, but also is a well-educated community, and the public outreach component of the restructuring effort has involved many public officials and knowledgeable citizens who understand the value of asking good questions to a transit agency when they’re looking to deploy services,” Chad says. “We’ve found Remix to be really productive for our purposes in using all the mapping layers, because people will make comparisons about neighborhoods and we’re able to pull up the data with Remix much more efficiently than without the program. All of those layers have helped to inform our process of meeting the route service to where more transit-dependent populations are.”Chad has also employed Jane throughout the outreach process. Though it took him three or four times at different meetings to explain it succinctly, he says that the lightbulb ultimately went off for his audience: They were able to say, “I live right in the middle of that dot, right next to where Jane was, and I see how much further I can now travel as opposed to the old plan.”“I live right in the middle of that dot, right next to where Jane was, and I see how much further I can now travel as opposed to the old plan.”CDTA will implement its route restructuring in May. Meanwhile, the CDTA planning team has also been using Remix to create iterations of routes. Seeing ridership and demographic information change instantly as a result of new frequency inputs is a huge time-saver for CDTA, which only has two staffers dedicated to scheduling and service planning and three to strategic, long-range planning.We each wear a lot of different hats, and having Remix in our toolbox helps to generate a lot of these maps much faster, and has certainly helped our process in presenting information to public officials and citizens at large“We each wear a lot of different hats, and having Remix in our toolbox helps to generate a lot of these maps much faster, and has certainly helped our process in presenting information to public officials and citizens at large,” Chad says. CDTA’s GIS scheduling system administrator has found it easiest and most aesthetically pleasing to build maps in Remix, thanks to its snap-to feature for routing, and exports shapefiles to make publicly available route maps.For an agency like CDTA, which operates a mix of services, Remix has led to more nimble planning processes that are easy for its riders to understand. “I am a very strong advocate for leveraging technology in our small planning office. It certainly helps us to generate lots of productive output,” says Chad. “That requires a little investment in technology.”

title: Planning the Impossible: Launching a New Bus System in One Year

title: Antelope Valley Transit Authority Answers Questions in Fifteen Minutes Flat
content: Antelope Valley Transit Authority Answers Questions in Fifteen Minutes FlatUsing Remix Live at Board MeetingsRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 14, 2016The Antelope Valley Transit Authority’s fleet of 75 buses serves over 450,000 residents in Lancaster, Palmdale, and the unincorporated portions of northern Los Angeles County, with over 1,200 square miles connecting the Antelope Valley to the rest of Los Angeles and Kern counties. It recently adjusted its processes for service changes: Now, AVTA makes modifications to schedules (if needed) every six months coinciding with the operators shake-up.Remix has recently been my go-to tool for quickly calculating cost, vehicle requirements and demographic details — easily allowing me to compare existing service with proposed new service or rerouting of existing serviceWith the latest comprehensive operational analysis, AVTA began to incorporate ongoing minimal service tweaks in January, with major modifications being conducted in June. “We cover approximately 1,200 square miles of service area, with the population densities focused within the cities of Lancaster, Palmdale and unincorporated areas of Los Angeles County. Doing more with less is key in service development and scheduling,” says senior planning officer Dietter Aragon. “Remix has recently been my go-to tool for quickly calculating cost, vehicle requirements and demographic details — easily allowing me to compare existing service with proposed new service or rerouting of existing service.”The June changes will affect eight current lines of its local service; AVTA is combining some and restructuring their names, as well as shifting around weekend service and adding new services to better serve the community. Currently, Saturdays and Sundays follow the same schedule, but Sunday ridership is far lower. The June changes will boost Saturday service and possibly institute holiday service.Dietter has been pleased with Remix’s ability to quickly calculate cost, miles, hours and additional demographic views, along with the number of buses AVTA will need to execute its service changes. He frequently uses the links and export tools Remix provides to present data to AVTA’s executive team for review.He’s hoping that the same sort of clear communication will ease the process of explaining to riders why AVTA will be changing service that’s familiar to them, or making changes that don’t seem immediately beneficial. “We’re going to be taking Remix to the public, so when we do our outreach, we’ll be able to show this live to the public and talk about each route one by one. The beauty about Remix is that you can show how effective or ineffective a service is or can be, simply by turning on a few layers.”Dietter plans to take his laptop to all the public meetings and project a Remix map on-screen, so that he can talk about specific changes. “I think this sends a stronger message than a couple PowerPoint slides. PowerPoint is great, but, we sometimes get comments like, ‘How about having loop around there? Or what if you extend the service by 30 minutes?’ Well, now we can show our customers in real time and they can see how that impacts cost.”Additionally, Remix has amped up Dietter’s day-to-day workflow. Dietter tells us about the day that his executive director asked him to figure out how much a certain route scenario would cost. “I think I was on a conference call during that time too, but it literally took me less than fifteen minutes to give him a fairly concise report. I received an email back that read ‘Wow, that was fast’. Dietter estimates that assembling information from Google Earth, GIS, and Excel for the same kind of request would of taken at least an hour.With Remix, we’ll be able to use this tool to show the public, our Technical Advisory Committee and our Board Members how these changes will benefit their community.In February, Dietter presented an overview of his proposed service changes to AVTA’s Board of Directors. He’ll take them to the public next, and in March and April, he’ll begin scheduling the routes. After delivering final recommendations to the board at the end of April, everything should be said and done by May for a go-live In June. “There’s definitely going to be a lot of great changes for the community. We have a great team here,” Dietter says. “With Remix, we’ll be able to use this tool to show the public, our Technical Advisory Committee and our Board Members how these changes will benefit their community.”

title: Balancing Ridership vs. Coverage: Best Practices from Silicon Valley, CA
content: Balancing Ridership vs. Coverage: Best Practices from Silicon Valley, CARemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 18, 2016Jay Tyree from VTA in Santa Clara, CA, describes how Remix has democratized the ridership vs. coverage tradeoff of their current COA.VTA, in the heart of California’s Silicon Valley, is in the midst of planning its first major service change in almost 10 years. Jay Tyree, service planner at VTA, sees the core challenge of the network redesign as a tradeoff between ridership and coverage: Should VTA maximize for ridership with frequent, all day service in only the densest areas? Or should they aim for wider coverage throughout the service area with less frequent service?VTA is exploring three ridership vs. coverage scenarios to answer common questions about the bus network.In his talk at this year’s Remix Conference, Tyree discusses how VTA has used Remix to democratize the decision process by arming the public with the information they need to understand the underlying give-and-take. Using Remix’s simple visualizations to clearly communicate the core problem during public outreach, VTA is moving away from the technique Tyree describes as “trust us, we’re service planners.”You can watch his talk here:

title: Exporting from Remix
content: Exporting from RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 30, 2015Remix is an excellent platform to be able to quickly sketch new and modify existing transit lines. In addition, features like Jane enable you to visualize the reach of your transit network like never before. However, we understand there are often unique or custom analyses that you may require for your workflow.Remix exports into four different formats. I’ll briefly describe what each of those exports contains:So let’s start with an example map in Medford, OR.You’ll notice this map only has five active lines (two lines are turned off). Each export will only use the five active lines and will ignore those turned off. I’m going to use this map to export in each of the four formats.Excel (.xlsx)When exporting from Remix into Microsoft Excel, nearly all of the Setting inputs and route schedule information is converted into spreadsheet format. No spatial data (lines, stops) are exported. The spreadsheet will include a summary tab, and an individual tab corresponding to each line on the exported map (in this example, five).Summary Tab You’ll notice the default settings used in this map (costs, layover rules, calendar days) and a line-by-line summary showing mileage, peak buses, hours and dollars per year (based on the calendar settings).Individual Line Tab These tabs show similar information as the summary tab but go a step further to display the characteristics for each service window. In this example, the 2 West Medford only has a single service window (6:00A-7:00P).Google Earth (.kml)KML is a file format most typically used with Google Earth. When opening a KML file in Google Earth, Remix produces line information but not the associated schedules or settings. In the below example, you can see the different lines that have been imported. I’ve recolored the 2-West Medford to demonstrate where they are relative to the rest of the network.Shapefile (.shp)Shapefiles are typically opened by ArcMap or other GIS software packages like QGIS. When exporting to shapefile, Remix exports both the spatial information (lines) and schedule information.In this example, I’ve opened my shapefile in a free GIS program called QGIS. Here, you can see the transit lines displayed on the map.The associated attribute table shows each individual line’s name and other characteristics such as mileage, frequency, and peak vehicles (information consistent with what is produced in the Excel file). You can use these characteristics to select different symbologies to recolor lines as needed.GTFS (.txt)Remix exports valid frequency-based GTFS. Frequency-based GTFS does not include the level of specificity as trip-based GTFS, which includes detail of every transit trip in the schedule. Frequency-based GTFS includes detail about service windows and associated trip frequency within those windows. For example, frequency-based GTFS describes 15 minute service between 7AM-8AM just as that, and would not specifically define trip start times. As a result, one should take caution before directly comparing Remix GTFS (frequency-based) with GTFS produced by scheduling software (trip-based) as it is not an apples-to-apples comparison.Here’s an example of the file package included as part of the GTFS export.Currently, Remix does not export bus stops as part of its other exports. However, we do produce a stops.txt file which provides stop latitude and longitudes which can be geocoded in other software. The stops.txt also includes a stop_id which can be reassociated to trips (and their associated line name) through a manual linking process.Have additional questions or feedback on these exports? Let us know!

title: Biz Collins of Mesa County, Colorado
content: Biz Collins of Mesa County, ColoradoRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 30, 2015Biz Collins is a transportation planner with Mesa County, Colorado’s regional transportation planning organization. RTPO — which sets schedules and routes for Grand Valley Transit and takes feedback from its riders and drivers — is continually seeking to improve and expand service without increasing costs. This past spring, RTPO planners began route modifications that reduced duplication and switched inbound and outbound paths.We interviewed Biz about the particular challenges of planning for Mesa County (which has an exceptionally long route map), and she told us what it’s like to use web-based maps in a public outreach process.Can you tell me about the demographics of Mesa County and the riders you work with? There’s a population of 150,000 total. The bus system serves the metropolitan area, which is Grand Junction, Palisade, and the unincorporated areas in between. The primary trip purpose is between work and home, which we know from onboard surveys. We’ve captured the transit-dependent population, who is who we really serve right now — those without a vehicle, minorities, the LEP population. We’re working on branching into choice riders and high-density areas, like anywhere with apartment buildings. Mesa County is conservative politically. It’s dry, it’s hot, it’s beautiful.I came into this office about eight months before we got Remix. We had done a route modification before then; this one is my first. From what I understand, the process was getting in the vehicle and driving the route. The planners would look at GIS maps, then Google-mapped drive time to estimate it. It wasn’t perfect because it was inaccurate. Physically getting in a car doesn’t give you the real transit experience because it’s hard to keep the same speed. Finally, they’d ride a bus. It was a lot longer of a process and was more complicated with more inaccuracies.Can you tell me about using Remix for public involvement? We used it to provide a visual display of the routes. I’m a visual person, and the majority of people are, too. Having a map for people to see without it being such a big file that you can’t download, or it being a GIS file that you can’t use — Remix was a way that we could share ideas and proposed routes, and they could zoom in and out to see how it would affect their path and route to wherever they go. We got a lot of comments directly from the map — the “send a comment” elicited a lot of responses.Our website had a page dedicated to proposed route changes. We had a link right there to check out proposed routes visually and had a verbal description below that included stops. We directed people to the website and they could follow along.It was nice to be able to share this with our dispatch and road supervisors, various staff who aren’t so fluent or familiar with GIS. Frequently, one on-the-ground perspective was very different from the planner perspective. Letting them use the same tools that we’re using is very empowering, and we can get more helpful feedback. (RTPO asked for another login for certain emails so dispatchers and operators were able to access it on their computers. They could share maps and during the route modification process, the planners received some maps from them.) We’ll continue to do this in the future.I think we can test innovative ideas more easily and get more creative with routes and service and options by seeing them in a dry run. That’s really helpful, and it’s a lot easier thinking down the road about major changes.Based on times, this has reduced labor on the transportation-planner end. I’m benefitting a lot, but it benefits the public for that visual component. Our system map is huge, and if they can’t download a document because of slow Internet, they can’t view a PDF. This is so much more user-friendly for the average Joe, and it allows them to interact with the proposed maps.What have you been doing with your newfound free time? Playing with our electronic fare boxes!Remix is interviewing planners about their innovative work in public transit. This is the first in a series.mesa-county public-engagement meet-our-planners

title: What’s New in Remix
content: What’s New in RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJun 18, 2016We make improvements to Remix every day. We’ve collected some of the bigger changes on this page, so you can see what’s new.The “Showdown in Motown” Release (v11)August 2016Rapid schedule editor. A much faster way of editing schedules, similar to excel. Add, remove, and modify windows using just your keyboard.Adjustable buffer distance. Set the catchment area to any distance between 0.1 miles and 2 miles to get the associated demographics. Also works with metric values.Favorite stats. A big upgrade that lets you “star” your favorite stats and demographics, and have them always appear in the statistics pane. New statistics include daily costing and average stop spacing.Export stops. KML and Shapefile exports now include bus stops, including a list of which routes go through which stops. You can take these into GIS to further analysis on the routes you design.Trip-based costs. An experimental feature that generates individual trips (9:05, 9:15, 9:25…) and uses those to get more accurate costing. Also lets you specify inbound-only and outbound-only windows in the schedule pane.Custom colors. Use hex values to specify the exact color of your route. Useful for matching your transit agency’s branding.And lots more:Estimate Stops makes a come-back. It now intelligently finds existing stops, then inserts new stops for portions of the route that don’t have nearby infrastructure.Zooming with a scroll-wheel is now more accurate.Press ‘0’ (zero) to zoom all the way out.A revamped help-site with answers to your most common questions.

title: Using Remix for Day-to-Day Planning in Louisville, KY
content: Using Remix for Day-to-Day Planning in Louisville, KYRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingDec 3, 2015The Transit Authority of River City serves Louisville, Kentucky and its greater metropolitan area — which is largely low-density and sprawling. Though the region has major employment centers, they frequently spring up outside of TARC’s service areas, and a considerable amount of effort from the agency goes into determining if it’s feasible to bring transit to those centers.Here’s how Josh Poe, a transit planner at TARC, describes the many steps involved in making those decisions:“Transit operating cost generally consists of three variables; time-based cost, distance-based cost, and vehicle-based cost. Prior to Remix, transit planners estimated these costs using separate software systems. First, a GIS system was used to calculate distances, then Excel or a third party scheduling software was employed to calculate hours per day, from which you could calculate how many vehicles needed. This was a long process, particularly if you wanted to compare the cost of extending existing routes or adding a new route. However, transit service decisions are not based purely on financial motives: There are federal regulations involving civil rights, along with conflicting ridership goals versus coverage goals, so a demographic data analysis was also necessary, which involves analyzing Census data in GIS. This was a convoluted process, but Remix has combined these steps into one simple format.”Josh says that fulfilling these requests well enough to make comparisons once took a few days to a week. With Remix, he’s able to do that level of data analysis — to answer questions like, “What is the cost of extending a route to serve an employer? or “Which route do we extend if we want to extend it?” — in drastically less time.“I can take now take separate routes, add extensions to those, or create a new route and get costing estimates and demographic numbers in a couple hours. Once I have it in that format, that’s very easy to share with management so that they can make decisions,” Josh says. “As in any organization, management doesn’t need to wade through complex details. They want information quickly, and they want it to be simple and concise so they can make better, more informed decisions.”TARC’s planners initially attracted to Remix for its costing capability, given the numerous requests they receive to answer those kinds of “what-if” questions. But Josh has used Remix in a multitude of ways:For project-level cost estimates: Josh has used Remix to determine the preliminary costs of a TIGER-funded BRT project and to analyze three transit projects within Move Louisville (pictured above), the city’s comprehensive transportation plan.As a database: Josh has built “templates” in Remix, so that he can copy a map and adjust headways or running time. As his database has become more robust, he’s been able to field “what-if” questions even more rapidly.As a research tool: To see demographics within a quarter mile of a specific stop, Josh will draw “a line on that stop, as if it were a transit route,” and pull up the demographic information.Additionally, Josh used Remix to evaluate reducing redundancy on a particular corridor with three routes. He was able to increase the span of service, the frequency, and the coverage; provide better service on weekends; and make it almost cost-neutral.“I could have done it without Remix, but it would have been such a time-consuming process,” he says. “The time of planning, and the management of information, has changed so much with Remix. It’s such a great tool and such a rich resource.”Photo via Flickr

title: Let’s Plan a Fiesta! A Case Study on Detours
content: Let’s Plan a Fiesta! A Case Study on DetoursRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingAug 5, 2015VIA Metropolitan Transit is based in San Antonio, TX and has been using Remix to sketch and plan their system detours.Over the past few weeks, we’ve been watching VIA’s transit planning team (with increased fascination) as they vigorously mapped out routes called “Fiesta.” We called up Art Herrera, a senior planner at VIA, to see what the party was all about.Turns out, Fiesta is an annual tradition in San Antonio, where the streets downtown explode into a nonstop two-week bash with parades, block parties, and concerts.While thrilling for the city, it’s tough on the local transit agency — who must grapple with detours and street closures at the exact same place where most of the service converges for their hub-and-spoke system. During certain days of Fiesta, over half of VIA’s routes must be modified to ensure ongoing connections for its 150K daily riders, an immense undertaking.For decades, it’s been a challenge for VIA to design detours and schedules during Fiesta due to many alignment changes and unpredictable activity of the event. To provide some clarity, they’ve tried manually managing vehicles locations and spacing with road supervisors and dispatchers tracking vehicle locations. Yet, operators could never tell if they were on time and most importantly, it was nearly impossible for the general public to know when the bus was actually coming.This year, instead of using traditional tools to plan for 2016’s raucous event, they are using Remix to envision alternatives. “By drawing out the modified/cut/detoured routes, we can see what headways we can provide given the existing number of vehicles… and do this relatively quickly and easily,” said Art.Here’s a snapshot of one line they’re planning.With their new-found experience drawing for Fiesta, VIA is also trying out a few other things in Remix. “It has been extremely useful in the development of service plans for 5-year capital plans.”Pretty cool stuff. I think we should all do a site visit to San Antonio for Fiesta to see how it’s working out!

title: Introducing Route Pattern Imports in Remix
content: Introducing Route Pattern Imports in RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 19, 2015Transit routes often don’t just travel from point A to B. Resource limitations or a need for special trips on routes result in different “patterns” or “variants” throughout the day. These patterns can include trips that travel some portions of the route’s full length.Remix’s beta version of pattern imports means that our platform now more accurately replicates the patterns that exist in transit networks.Until recently, Remix would evaluate a transit agency’s GTFS data and import the longest “shape” of a route, regardless of any patterns. Now, you can import individual patterns for each route in your system.When you click “Import” on the left sidebar, you’ll see a dropdown arrow next to the agency name that will reveal a toggle that allows you to “Import route patterns.” When toggled on, you’ll see the patterns for routes within your system shown as different letters.Once imported, these patterns appear in Remix as separate routes so you can evaluate them individually. For example, here AC Transit Line 11 is imported as three patterns: 11A, 11B, 11C.Route patterns are made possible by parsing your agency’s GTFS and looking for slight differences in scheduled time points and stop locations. When we notice that one trip differs greatly from another, we consider that a separate pattern.We’re excited to be able to provide this additional level of detail for existing routes. Remix users can try out patterns today, and we would love to hear how they are working for you!

title: Remix Pro Tips and Tricks: The Top Five
content: Remix Pro Tips and Tricks: The Top FiveRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 20, 2016We’ve heard that Remix is great because it’s easy to use and fast. Here are a few tips we’ve heard from around the Remix Community to help you plan transit even faster!1) Use Multiple Remix Map WindowsIf you’d like to compare the vital stats for two line alternatives, open up multiple browser windows to see them side-by-side. Since Remix is web-based, you can open up multiple Remix maps at any given time to see the whole story.Also, remember you can print a line summary for any line on your map.2) Use keyboard shortcutsIf you have a line selected, can use the J and K keys to quickly scroll through other lines on your map. This is really useful if you are comparing two lines and want to toggle back and forth to quickly compare their results.You can also use the I and O keys to toggle back and forth between the inbound (I) and outbound (O) direction of a line.Finally the + and — buttons can be used to zoom in and out of your map. These zoom buttons (like the ones on the screen) are sometimes more precise as compared to using the scroll wheel on your mouse.3) Ctrl+F to search your mapSince Remix works in any standard internet browser, standard shortcuts apply such as Ctrl+P to print and Ctrl+F to find. The latter is particuarly useful if you’re trying to import a line within a long list of services. By using the standard browser search feature, you can quickly identify the line you’re seeking without scrolling through a longer list.4) Be CreativeWe’ve heard lots of creative strategies about how people use Remix. Here are a few examples:Splitting lines into two directions to represent peak-direction serviceUsing bus stops as a way to capture demographics for future bikeshare stationsPlanning deviated-fixed route service by drawing a normal line, but simply slowing down the travel speed (accounting for deviations)Capturing a location’s demographics by simply dropping a bus stop on that location (and not drawing the remainder of the line)Posting a Remix map on the agency’s website with ongoing route detours for public informationAs you become more familiar with Remix, don’t be afraid to use it in ways that fit your needs that might not fit the norm!5) Ask the Success TeamThere are several workflows that we can help with on the back-end such as merging maps together, adding custom data layers, and more. If you have a specific request, let us know and we may be able to help.

title: Bringing Remix Into the Field With Pace Suburban Bus
content: Bringing Remix Into the Field With Pace Suburban BusRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 1, 2016The swath of the Chicago metropolitan area, from the borders of Indiana to Wisconsin, is covered by Pace Suburban Bus. Its sister agencies, CTA and Metra, provide the bulk of transit to Chicago as well as within the city’s downtown commuter market; Pace takes on the vast span — over 3,500 miles — outside of it with fixed-route, vanpool, and dial-a-ride services.Pace is one of the largest bus networks in North America and is increasingly focused on the growing markets of “the outward, away-from downtown commuter market to suburban centers,” says Ryan Ruehle, a service planner at Pace. “Most recently, we’ve been trying to implement more regional rapid types of services,” which will provide suburban-to-downtown, suburban-to-city, and suburban-to-suburban connections. Not to mention, Pace also provides paratransit service within the entire six-county region of northeastern Illinois, and is expanding express services to downtown Chicago via interstate highways.Ryan joined Pace just under a year ago, around the time that the agency began using Remix. He’s used it to analyze a potential route extension to a retail center, generating different demographic maps to show the proximity of the proposed routing to the concentration of those demographics — primarily population density and levels of disadvantaged populations.I’ve been using Remix a lot to flesh out a lot of ideas that I have, both in terms of potential and new bus routes and for making modifications to existing routes. It’s a really great way to put lines and stops down on a map and try to gauge whether or not that’s going to work in real lifeRemix’s sketching feature has been particularly helpful in helping Ryan understand what route configurations he should pursue: “I’ve been using Remix a lot to flesh out a lot of ideas that I have, both in terms of potential and new bus routes and for making modifications to existing routes. It’s a really great way to put lines and stops down on a map and try to gauge whether or not that’s going to work in real life, and kind of refine things from there.”Ryan also uses Remix as a field reference: He’ll open it up on a browser on his phone or tablet and sign in to flip between the maps he’s produced in Remix when recording route timings to see how much time it takes to get between to time points of a route or route segment. “I’ve got a mount for the cell phone and everything,” he says. “Just having it there and having a reference map saves me from getting lost, maybe, here or there, and making sure that I’m doing things the way in which I wanted to do them when I was sitting in the office, thinking it out before.”It’s enhanced my ability to really suss out the wheat from the chaff in terms of what ideas for routes are going to work or not.“It’s enhanced my ability to really suss out the wheat from the chaff in terms of what ideas for routes are going to work or not — which ones to focus time and energy and investment into rather than putting that time and investment into all the ideas you might have,” says Ryan. “It’s really good at helping target which ones to go after.”

title: Scenario Planning and Service Tweaks in Pierce County, WA
content: Scenario Planning and Service Tweaks in Pierce County, WARemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 4, 2016“We started using Remix when we were developing one of our growth scenarios for our long-range plan,” says Max Henkle, a senior planner at Pierce Transit in Washington state. Pierce Transit serves the southern Puget Sound region and, while its Destination 2040 plan wasn’t designed completely in Remix, Max used our platform to illustrate an included aspirational scenario — a total reinvention of the network. Rather than redrawing the Pierce Transit’s entire network in GIS, Max drew it in Remix, along with a.m. peak frequencies, and exported it as a shapefile.But long-range plans don’t happen every day. Pierce’s planners are constantly evaluating routes on a short- and medium-range basis, and in doing so, typically draw out every iteration of a change that they can imagine. Exploring so many different options allows Max and his team to come up with compromises that “make the most number of riders happy, or perform the best,” he says. “With Remix, it makes it easier to explore that intellectually, rather than taking those ideas and manually digitizing everything, then calculating the service requirements.” Regionally, service changes now take place in March and September, so tweaks that Max is considering could take place then.Pierce Transit is also using Remix to consider different scenarios for a proposed BRT line over its most productive route, which could be anywhere from seven to 20 miles. “There are a lot of ways to skin a cat,” Max says, and he’s used Remix throughout the development of three main scenarios: “We would draw it out, where we thought the proposed termini were, along with the proposed route, and that quickly gives us an estimate of not only the service hours and miles for each of those scenarios, roughly how many people and jobs and other demographic factors are nearby.”As those scenarios are further developed, they’ll be taken to Pierce Transit’s board, to focus groups, and, eventually, to the public — all of which will come with input and negotiations. “When you’re trying to sell something to someone in a meeting, when you’re trying to get your executives engaged and there are these heated discussions about “Why don’t we just turn around at this transit center? Why do we have to go all the way to downtown Tacoma?” and it’s handy to be able to say, “Well, when we draw this line over here, Remix tells us that we can serve an additional 14,000 jobs within a quarter-mile of those downtown stops” he says. “So it makes it a more compelling argument for why you’re doing things a certain way when you can quickly see what the efficacy of where you’re placing the stops and how you’re structuring the route.”Customer comments aren’t beholden to the occasions of particular planning initiatives, and Max has also used Remix to answer inquiries about general service patterns. When a customer submitted a comment, he sketched out the hypothetical out in Remix, “just to see what it looked like and to see if it made sense,” he says. “For those quick little investigations — reality-checking something — it’s kind of handy.”For more about Pierce Transit, read our interview with Max Henkle.Photo via Flickr

title: New: Quickdraw and a built-in Stops Database
content: New: Quickdraw and a built-in Stops DatabaseTwo of our biggest updates ever. Available to everyone, today.RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 12, 2016We’ve redesigned the drawing experience in Remix to allow you draw concepts quickly, accurately, taking advantage of our knowledge of existing bus stop infrastructure. We’ve called these new features QuickDraw and Stops 2.0 and they transform drawing in Remix.Here’s a 5-minute demonstration:“So intuitive you don’t need much training, I understood the new features very quickly”– Chris Loader, Public Transport VictoriaFrequently Asked QuestionsWe have meticulously designed these new features to be simple and clear. However, we understand there are questions with a change this big. Here are five common questions:What are the differences between stops and pins?Stops represent actual bus stops. Remix will calculate nearby demographic information based on stops. Pins tell Remix where to place the bus line. Think of it like “pinning” a string to a map to represent your bus line. If you want to modify an existing or draw a new line, you’ll use pins.Can I add bus stops (in addition to those already in my system)?Yes! Remix will automatically import existing bus stops based on your transit agency. However, if you want to add a bus stop, simply right click on the line and you’ll be prompted to “Create new stop”. You’ll have the option to add a bus stop name. This stop will be visible on this map (and other maps copied from this map). However, if you create a brand new map, this stop will not appear.What happens to my current maps?Your current maps are absolutely safe and we haven’t changed anything (including lines and bus stops). However, you have the option to “upgrade” your maps to take advantage of the new bus stops information (including bus stop names and stop IDs). Simply click on “Find stops” in the line options menu above the line name).By clicking on “Find stops” Remix will rematch all of the map’s stops (actual and proposed) to the existing bus stops based on your agency’s GTFS loaded into Remix. If you have any concerns, you can always make a copy of your map before running our stopfinder.Important Note: Because many agencies place stops differently, our stopfinder process may require some modification. If you see something odd, let us know and we’ll investigate!With Stops 2.0, we take advantage of existing GTFS data including the bus stop name and stop id. You can access this information by right clicking on the bus stop itself.What stops are saved in the GTFS export?One of the most exciting things about Stops 2.0 is information on existing vs. new bus stops when modifying your system. The stops.txt file in the GTFS export already produces a list of bus stops. You now can differentiate between existing stops and created stops through the stop_id field. Existing bus stops will maintain your agency’s original stop identification code, while Remix created stops will be appended with remix-.We look forward to hearing your thoughts on these exciting new features! Give them a try today and let us know your questions and feedback!

title: Meet a Planner: Marvin Ranaldson of Sandusky, Ohio
content: Meet a Planner: Marvin Ranaldson of Sandusky, OhioRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 2, 2015Transportation in Sandusky, Ohio is a one-man show. Its fixed-route and demand-response services, which see, respectively, about 140,000 and 60,000 trips per year, are all under the purview of Marvin Ranaldson, Sandusky’s transit administrator. Marvin worked as a bike messenger; with All Aboard Ohio; and as Bike Cleveland’s volunteer and outreach manager before taking over transit in the rollercoaster capital of the world.But Sandusky’s transit doesn’t just serve Cedar Point: There’s the 800-room Kalahari Resort; a historic downtown core with many no-car households; and miles of rural Erie County, which has a considerable senior population. “Our ridership has grown 15 percent per year for the past five years, but I know we can do better,” Marvin tells us.Marvin is using Remix to orchestrate a system redesign that will combat overcrowding and scheduling issues, so we checked in with him to learn what the challenges his system faces. With three current routes, the city of Sandusky is Remix’s smallest, but perhaps mightiest, customer.What kind of work have you been doing with Remix specifically? We need to do a system redesign because our travel times point to point are really atrocious. First of all, we have three individual routes and they all go in a counterclockwise fashion, so they’re all one-way. One-way transit routes are really good in one direction, but really bad in the other. It’s really difficult to get them to work well, especially, so, I have a route that goes 23 miles. It’s a lot. It’s difficult to make the transit service more attractive unless we can do something about the travel times. They can’t stay on schedule, either, because they’re just stretched. The schedules are a little bit too optimistic and we get behind.Can you tell me more about process for this redesign? I started it. I got some feedback from some people in City Hall. We’re going to begin our formal public meetings and feedback sessions early next year. The gist of it is, we’re going to go from three to five routes. All of them will be two-way and bidirectional. I’m splitting up some of our peak loads so our trips that are going out to Kalahari, which is a huge driver of traffic for us. I’m going to have two buses, two individual routes serve it going in opposite directions to split that load up. Even with our large transit buses, we’ve been overcrowding those buses servicing [Kalahari], because they’re all getting off at the same time. We just don’t have enough vehicles there to take care of that.Will you need to purchase new vehicles? My hope is, to be honest, our 40-foot buses aren’t new, they’re used, they’re over 16 years old, so we got them used. I’m hoping I can either replace them with smaller, more cost-effective buses — basically, replace one bus with two buses going in different directions to handle that traffic flow, or just have one big bus on the route like we have now, but not have the overcrowding issues we have now.You’re mostly serving service workers, right?Right. We have the core of Sandusky, where everything’s built up. It’s very urban. It doesn’t seem like it would be, but it’s very urban. It’s a very old city. We have all the people who live in the city, they don’t have cars. We send them out to the nearby suburb — there’s only one suburb. We send them out there to get to work, and that’s where all the shopping is, as well. But the rest of the county is farmland, small towns, little villages that don’t have access, and there are some elderly there that don’t have access to vehicles, and they need to get to the grocery store. We have a lot of people taking the bus into town to get to the hospital. We have the largest medical center in northern Ohio.How does your demand-response system work?We don’t have paratransit like a big city does. We have demand-response, which covers the entire county, which is 100 square miles or so. Most of our ridership comes from 20 square miles around Sandusky. We had to find ways to do it more efficiently and be more cost-effective.That’s where we find the greatest opportunity to grow, because demand-response has been stagnant over the past six years. All the growth has come through our fixed routes, but demand-response has gotten more and more expensive. We found some ways to reduce the cost of that and that allows us to focus more on fixed routes.Why is demand-response not cost-effective — because the area’s so big and not very dense? Yeah, it’s sending one bus to pick up two people, or sending one bus to go to the door to pick up a person, when you could send them to one bus stop and make it more of a scheduled route. That’s more cost-effective to do. Walmart, for example — I get so many demand-response trips going to Walmart, or going to Kroger, that somehow consolidating those trips onto one bus or one vehicle makes it a lot more cost-effective. Those are the people who need our service the most.So how did you get into transportation planning?I started out as a bike messenger when I graduated high school, and I went into mechanical engineering with a focus on automotive engineering. My first interaction with transit was on a bike and through cars, making cars, thinking about cars. I decided it sucked. I’ve been overseas, I’ve visited places, and I’ve seen how it can be done differently. In many ways, transit goes toward my analytical side, but also to my heart, which tries to help people. As an urban planner, which I’m trained as, there just isn’t a strong core of transportation, like how transportation affects development and all this other stuff that we spend time trying to fix.

title: When’s the Bus Coming? How to Adjust your Line’s Schedule
content: When’s the Bus Coming? How to Adjust your Line’s ScheduleRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 20, 2015At Remix, we know that transit schedules are complicated, so we’ve made a line’s schedule viewable in a straightforward format. Once you’ve learned what one row means, you’ve learned them all!Take a look at this schedule for the 21-Hayes in San Francisco:Our schedule breaks down a service into separate service days: weekday, Saturday, and Sunday. Below is how weekday service looks in Remix. We’ll use this example to walk through what each column means:From, To: These describe the service windows, or the times between which the service is operating. The above example of weekday service shows that the 21-Hayes operates between 5 a.m. and 6:30 a.m.Every: This represents frequency. Here, 21-Hayes is operating every 18 minutes between 5 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. on weekdays.Runtime: This is the estimated transit runtime based on the combined inbound and outbound route length and speed. If the speed increases and the route’s length stays the same, the runtime will go down. If the speed stays the same and the length increases, the runtime will go up.Layover: This represents the time needed at the end of the line for schedule recovery and driver breaks. Layover is a fixed number based on the settings in your Remix map. You can adjust the layover settings to be a percentage of the runtime or a fixed number of minutes. Here, the 21-Hayes’ layover is set at 10 percent of the runtime.Speed: The estimated running speed of the route includes dwell time at stops, but does not include the time when the bus is stopped during layover. Traffic congestion, presence of transit-only lanes or facilities, the number of bus stops, and locations with high dwell time (meaning, lots of passengers) can impact a bus’ speed. Remix does not automatically determine these factors. When we import your agency’s GTFS data, we estimate a line’s speed based on its length and schedule information.Buses: Based on a line’s length, speed, and frequency, Remix estimates the number of buses required. For example, if your runtime is 60 minutes and your frequency is 60 minutes, we estimate one bus. If your run time is 60 minutes, but your frequency is 30 minutes, we estimate two buses.Wiggle: Wiggle is a spot-check for a route’s efficiency: It shows how much time remains before an additional vehicle is needed. Extend the route’s length, lengthen the layover time, or change the frequency, and wiggle will help you gauge the “slack” in your schedule before adding that additional bus. In this example, 7.2 minutes remain before the 21-Hayes will require an additional bus, which would bring the total buses used on that line to 5 buses.Every row in the schedule can be edited to reflect different times of day. If you have a very simple schedule, you can use the “…” button on the right side of any schedule row to add or remove service windows. In the example below, I’ve deleted every service window (including Saturday and Sunday) except between 5 a.m.-6:30 a.m. I can click “…” and “Add service window” to add them back. If you are making numerous schedule edits, keyboard shortcuts exist that can make this process even faster.Now that you know the ins and outs of the line schedule panel, give it a try in Remix.

title: Meet a Planner: Josh Baker of GLTC in Lynchburg, VA
content: Meet a Planner: Josh Baker of GLTC in Lynchburg, VARemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 16, 2015Since his start as an operator in Blacksburg, Virginia, while attending Virginia Tech, Josh Baker has explored nearly every plane of the transportation universe. After college, he matched his business acumen with his belief in public transportation to start Radford, Virginia’s transit system. Now, he’s the general manager of Greater Lynchburg Transit Company, an established system in southern Virginia that can trace its roots back to the city’s horsedrawn carriage network.While overseeing the construction of a new operations and management facility, Josh is also strategizing how to bring GLTC to the next level, which, he tells us, involves “revising our routes, making our structure work better, implementing new technology, making the ridership experience better, improving the frequency of our service, the usability of our fare collection, and upping our focus on our customers.”Transitioning from an operator to a general manager has given Josh exceptional insight on how people use transit. We spoke to him about what it was like to build a system from the ground up and the challenges facing transportation planning in low-density, sprawling cities like Lynchburg.How has having an operations background helped you as a GM?I think this helps me understand what the drivers and maintenance personnel are going through. I understand what it takes to drive a bus and what goes on and how all of this comes together, and that helped me immensely in being able to build the Radford transit system from the ground up. Now I’ve come into GLTC, which is a very old system and has a lot of history, and come into a place where you’ve got a variety of challenges and things going on, and I can look at it from the perspective of a front-line person. Some of the world’s greatest success stories of positive, effective workplaces are companies that take their direction and guidance from their front line, because they know what’s going on.Are there specific instances of your operator knowledge in action?All the time! It comes into play when you think about the factors that cause a bus to be able to run on schedule, or not run on schedule; when you’re trying to sort out what are some trends in what’s going on with your operations and ridership. It gives you the ability have a better idea, beyond a hunch, where to look. For Radford, where I was going around setting up the locations of bus stops and understanding, drawing out on a map exactly where the route would go, I was able to do that in an effective way looking at the area because my intuition and understanding of how people move around and how they need connectivity came into play.The pieces really fell into place and we were in the right place at the right time. You have to be, in situations like this, to be ready to jump when you sense that people are buying in. That buy-in may only last for a year and then it’s gone. If you miss it, you missed it. It’s not going to come back. It excited me and I saw a need and I thought I could make a difference for the community, and I think we did. My reward is getting to see that and getting to see the effects. I can remember for the first year or two driving down the street in Radford: Seeing even one single person standing at one single bus stop was the greatest thing ever. It was the best thing to look at it. When you see that stop and you can say, damn, we put that bus stop there, we hammered the sign into the street, and we put the bus on the road — you’ll always remember that.What’s your ultimate dream for your agency, now that you’re at GLTC?I’d like to see us provide more frequent service throughout the city. I’d like to see us expand our choice riders. I’d like to see us put ourselves at the level that is high enough to attract the attention of those who otherwise might not consider riding our service. I don’t know if there’s a simple solution or a perfect way to get and recruit riders, but we’ll try. Most of the time, it’s economically driven. When gas prices are low and the economy’s doing well, it’s a different story than when people have tight budgets and tight situations to deal with.I personally don’t ride it regularly as a commuter, and I think that in itself is part of why I really want to improve what we do. Like many other choice riders, it’s just not frequent enough for me. I’ll often ride my buses as part of community outreach and to understand what the challenges are, but I wouldn’t be so naive as to claim to be someone who uses my system when I don’t. I think that I personally face the same challenges that many other choice riders face.What do you think about the future of transportation?I think that transit is something that is more heavily demanded by Millennials and Gen X, Gen Y than was by the Baby Boomers. It’s demanded to be more like your New Yorks, Chicagos, and San Franciscos. In order for a city to be viable and marketable to these younger generations, transit needs to be frequent; it needs to be clean; it needs to be accessible, convenient; and it needs to be technology-driven, with payment options like using your cell phone or credit card.I think it’s an industry that has a lot of catching up to do. I don’t know exactly how we’re going to do that, or in what way to convince all entities why transit is so important. Ultimately it’s about connecting all of the generations around a central issue, to provide accessibility and mobility to everybody.

title: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation Authority
content: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation AuthorityRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 7, 2016When the Puerto Rico Integrated Transportation Authority — known locally as ATI — was created by Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla in summer 2014, the island’s transportation paradigm was altered considerably in in terms of both new, different routes and service operations.EFGB Consulting Engineers was contracted by ATI to manage the design, planning, and adoption of the new routes. Its goal was to “reduce impact to the community to the minimum possible” during the agency shakeup, which brought down the number of lines from 37 to 27 overseen by ATI, says engineer Francisco Klein. Francisco and his team used Remix to assess the conditions of existing service prior to ATI’s conception, consider demographic and costing information for the new routes, and compare the two. In addition, the information provided by Remix was used in PRITA’s Title VI compliance report, justifying the changes from the 2013 routes to 2015 routes.We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked. What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?Jane, our isochrone, was particularly useful for Francisco’s work. “We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked,” he says, “What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?”Viewing Census data in Remix’s layers also helped his team see the social impact — particularly on senior, youth, and car-free populations — of the route changes. In Puerto Rico, taking transit is too often stigmatized as an indicator that you don’t have the ability to own a car, Francisco says. As a result, EFGB has focused on creating “an efficient and reliable system so that people who need it most use it and can say, ‘Yeah, this is working very well, and it’s meeting the goal and expectations,’ and that could eventually translate into more people seeing transit as an alternative.”While ATI is regulating and controlling the new routes planned for the Metropolitan Area of San Juan, the consultants have used Remix to consider systems in other municipalities of the island. Those local services will ultimately work with the systems and routes ATI proposes at an island-wide level. To foster strong and effective service between ATI and the municipal routes, Francisco focused on population data. “We didn’t want to have a system that would be spending too much money and having very limited ridership, so we made sure that we could reach areas with population concentration” in Aguadilla, on Puerto Rico’s north coast, and several municipalities on the southeastern side.I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually“I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually,” says Francisco. “You’d have to basically lay out the routes, and then go looking for the different layers in different systems. So having everything integrated right there, it’s just cost-effective, it’s efficient overall.”While data on ATI’s revamped bus system has yet to be calculated — the new lines were only implemented this past summer — Francisco says that his team “recognize[d] that some of the routes were just too long, and so Remix has been very helpful in assessing that the proposed routes are not as long as they used to be. That way, we think we’re taking one step in the right direction of having a more efficient and reliable system.”Moving forward, EFGB will do ride-check and point-check studies to determine the impact of the new routes. Once the data analysis process has been completed, they plan to continue to use Remix to assess potential route changes based on the collected data.
