title: Cutting Costs and Increasing Frequency in Greensboro, NC
content: Cutting Costs and Increasing Frequency in Greensboro, NCRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingDec 7, 2015When the Piedmont Authority for Regional Transportation needed to modify Route 9, a nearly four-hour roundtrip route between Lexington and Greensboro, North Carolina, its planners used Remix to cut costs and increase frequency.“We went to Remix, moved the route around, and explored cutting the section from High Point’s edge into Greensboro so we could take people all the way into downtown High Point,” says Kyle Laird, a mobility and systems planner at PART. “With the resulting difference in cost, we were able to increase frequency and make it much more attractive — not only getting the bus to places that people would like to go, but shortening the travel time.”Route 9 was originally planned over a decade ago. Then, the only data available to PART was raw commuter figures and a regional travel demand model that looked at the area within the four metropolitan planning organizations in the region — which didn’t align entirely with PART’s ten-county service area. When Kyle and his team looked at Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics data, they realized they weren’t connecting people from Davidson County to the most desired places. Remix enabled them to add PART’s specific costing information and view adjustments to the line on top of LEHD data, which should radically improve the efficiency and service of Route 9.“Plugging [revenue hour cost] in and moving the lines around was phenomenal for us and allowed us to say, yes, we can increase frequency if we can change the route,” Kyle says. By being able to estimate how much money we should save, we could say, all right, now we can pop in two roundtrips in the morning, two roundtrips in the evening, and one midday and still run it with one bus and two drivers. It really did help us see that it was possible for us to make some novel changes for our system of route analysis and planning.”Changes to Route 9 go into effect on January 11, so PART’s planners have been reaching out to riders to explain the upcoming changes. They’re hearing a groundswell of appreciation.“We got on the buses to talk to folks to tell them what we’re planning and why, and the public seemed to be understanding. No one was angry. The folks who were getting on at that one little stop at the edge of High Point, they were so excited because it would make things easier for them,” Kyle says. “The morning that I was riding it, it was a cold, misty morning and the folks out there, with no shelter, were really happy about the idea of catching the bus downtown at the transit center where there’s shelter and a waiting room. A lot of them had to catch a HiTran bus from somewhere else, go to the downtown transit center, and take another bus to get to the stop we served.”PART is using Remix to evaluate changes to another line, Route 10, with particular emphasis on Remix’s LEHD-based jobs data layer. Recommendations are expected by late spring. “We’ve got this mentality now that’s like, “Hey, let’s really think outside of the box and try all sorts of things to save some time, money, and really try to beef up frequency,” says Kyle, of using Remix for route modifications. “It gives you confidence when you have a tool that provides a good prediction of what should happen, cost-wise.”For more about PART, read our interview with director of planning Mark Kirstner.

title: Revisiting the Past to Inspire Future Transit in Eugene, OR
content: Revisiting the Past to Inspire Future Transit in Eugene, ORRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingFeb 24, 2016Lane Transit District serves the areas surrounding Eugene and Springfield, Oregon, south of Portland and about 50 miles from the Oregon Coast. LTD currently functions as a hub-and-spoke system, though as the region grows, explains Tim Simon, a service planner, LTD’s configuration is slowly changing.“Our downtown Eugene station is where most of our transfer activity occurs,” he says. “Transfers are essential, but we also are confined by the limited capacity of our station. As Eugene grows, so does the its need for improved transit — I kind of call Eugene a mid-major city that’s about to make the leap into a bigger city with more transit requirements. Station capacity is essential, so we’re really looking at making a jump from a hub-and-spoke to more of a hybrid.”As LTD plans for more crosstown connections — both organically and through a long-range planning process called Moving Ahead that includes building out the successful EmX BRT — Tim has employed Remix.Without Remix, a sketching session like that could have taken weeks.“How Remix really saves me time is instead of drawing something on, you know, taking a screenshot of Google and doing a hand-drawn line image, or doing something like that and submitting it to our graphics team and waiting on them to make a map, then realizing there’s a mistake and sending it back, I can do all this now and come up with unlimited scenarios within an hour,” he says. Without Remix, a sketching session like that could have taken weeks. Tim has also reduced the amount of time spent in either LTD’s scheduling software, or physically driving, to estimate a route’s potential costs.Plus, Tim has tackled a particularly confounding spot within LTD’s service area, a golf course among senior and low-income housing nicknamed the “donut hole.” Bounded by highways and a river, it lacks any effective through-routes, and over the past 30 years, LTD planners have struggled to connect it effectively to the rest of the system. Facing public pressure to route service through the donut hole once again, Tim used Remix to illustrate all seven lines that have served the area since 1985. He named each map the title of the historical route (see below) and the years it was active, and brought it to LTD’s board.We need to do something that hasn’t been done before, which is establish the frequency and serve the area with a crosstown route.“I put them all in there together so you can see how many iterations there are, just so [the board] understands that throwing out another one, a different configuration, that’s been done in the past and it’s not the way to go,” he says. “We need to do something that hasn’t been done before, which is establish the frequency and serve the area with a crosstown route. I think it’ll be a really interesting visual.”Moving Ahead, on top of LTD’s desire to develop more crosstown connections, “is going to be a big change for our customers,” says Tim — and is likely to move LTD closer to effectively connecting the donut hole to the rest of the system. “We have to do it slowly and make sure they understand the benefits of it.” Remix has drastically reduced the time LTD’s planners are spending testing ideas for greater mobility: With Remix, Tim says, “there’s so many different ways you can do that.”

title: Meet a Planner: Raymond Mui of DASH (Alexandria, VA)
content: Meet a Planner: Raymond Mui of DASH (Alexandria, VA)RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 19, 2015Raymond Mui is the director of planning and scheduling for DASH, which serves commuters, tourists, and everyone in between in Alexandria, Virginia, an independent city adjacent to Washington, D.C. Ask him what he does, and he’ll rattle off an impressive scope:“Everything from long-range, 20-year long-range planning all the way down to operator scheduling, runcutting, bidding, bid administration, and every step in between. We do long-range planning, we do short-range planning, we do annual budget developments, we do both short-range and long-range service planning and changes, route expansions and improvements, project implementation. We also have a large role in technology implementation and projects, so right now we’re in the middle of the implementation of our automated vehicle location system. We do our routine service and schedule changes, which includes assembling and administering the bidding process. This part of the year, we’re starting on our annual budgeting process for trading out budgets for the next year, our operating budget and our capital budget, which we do every year for a 10-year window. Also, we do a lot of grant work.”Deservedly so, Raymond landed on Mass Transit magazine’s 40 Under 40 list this year. While it’s unclear whether he’s the world’s youngest direct of planning and scheduling, we’re awed by the breadth and depth of his work. We talked to Raymond about the nuances of interagency coordination in the D.C. area and heard from him about what it’s like to revolutionize his agency’s heretofore paper-based planning processes.In what ways are you trying to push more tech, more data, and more innovative processes at DASH?Historically, especially before I came here, the kind of stuff we’ve been doing is very manual, very antiquated, paper-based, old-fashioned. Some of it we still do. A lot of what we do, I want to improve our efficiency in how we do it and the reliability and the comprehensiveness of all of our data. I think that the more or the better that we see and understand our system — and that has everything to do with how we collect our data and what data we have available to us — the more we are better able to improve our system and optimize efficiency, effectiveness, and the user experience. Without having adequate data to do your planning and your scheduling, it’s like trying to drive a car blind. That’s what we’re trying to improve on with the whole function of the department, which is to have an abundance of data available to us to do everything that we do. It’s not that data that we need or that we want, but data that we don’t even realize we can use to our benefit or advantage yet. So that’s one of the things we’re looking forward to with the implementation of the AVL system, APC technology, and Remix.For example, Remix specifically will open up a lot of capabilities to us that we previously have not had available in our department, like the ability to overlay different data sets and be able to determine what percentage of ridership is below the poverty level, or doesn’t have cars, or whatever specific alignment that we are developing a proposal for, as well as streamlining cost development, resource development, resource estimating, and cost estimating. It will help us streamline our process so we can do it in minutes instead of days.You know, what I’ve done, in the past, before Remix, what I’d usually do was take a screenshot of an online map, put it in Paint, and draw the lines on it. That’s how I used to draw my maps. We don’t have ArcGIS, none of that fancy stuff!Where do you think Alexandria will be in the next few years?The city of Alexandria is anticipating a lot of growth in the next 10 years. There are full-blown development plans for both ends of the city, a lot of transit-oriented development and infill development. There are three BRT transitways that we’ll be able to utilize to leverage our system. There’s going to be a big change in the composition of our land use and a big influx of not only residential and mixed-use development, but also commercial development. We’re anticipating a lot of growth and our long-range expansion plan is built out to anticipate all of these developments. We have service improvements built into our long-range expansion plan to accommodate all this growth to get people to use transit before they get in the habit of driving to and from either their residences or places of employment.If you look outside my window right now, I have a direct view of Old Town Alexandria and the Eisenhower East corridor. In addition to federal employers, such as PTO and DOD, moving to Alexandria in recent years, TSA has recently announced the relocation of its headquarters to Alexandria. These are huge employment shifts within the city.What do you think about the future of transportation at large?Transportation, I believe, is an ever-changing industry. It’s always evolving and what’s even more important is people’s perception or transit and what’s seen as the “norm.” The new generations, people are driving much less and they are finding, shifting toward other modes of transportation for commuting or recreational purposes or running errands, we find that a lot of people are moving away from the single-occupancy vehicle, but at the same time there are more options becoming available besides transit and besides the single-occupancy vehicle. There’s the recent introduction of Capital Bikeshare, Uber, Lyft, and similar services around the county.I believe the social perception of preferred transportation is evolving in the favor of alternative transportation and away from the automobile. I see that continuing in the future and it’s shaped recent and near-future development, which have become more transit-oriented, rather than auto-oriented. The majority of future developments, at least in Alexandria, are continuing this trend.

title: Pandora’s Top Spins: ‘I’m The One’ And ‘Despacito’ Remix Come In Hot
content: Pandora’s Top Spins: ‘I’m The One’ And ‘Despacito’ Remix Come In HotEmily BlakeBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 15, 2017Image Credit: Vevo.On this week’s Pandora Top Spins Chart, there’s the biggest thing in Latin music since “Macarena,” an early contender for Song of the Summer, and a new single from Trendsetter A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie. Read on for more from the chart, and check out the full list here.The LeadersAs Ed Sheeran’s “Shape of You” rides off into the sunset after a 16-week appearance on the chart—eight of those weeks at #1— Bruno Mars’ “What I Like” steps up to #1. While the original version racks up over 6 million spins weekly, the Gucci Mane-featuring remix rises five spots this week, just cracking the top 50.While “despacito” may be Spanish for “slowly,” there’s nothing slow at all about “Despacito (Feat. Justin Bieber),” the remix to Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee’s Latin pop hit. The original version has been a sensation of near-“Macarena” proportions, and Bieber’s presence is only making it bigger. This week, “Despacito (Feat. Justin Bieber)” debuts at #2, marking the highest-ever debut on the chart. Meanwhile, the original continues to see a steady rise, jumping three spots this week to #3.Elsewhere in the top 10, Kendrick Lamar’s swaggering “HUMBLE.” rises from #5 to #4, James Arthur’s sweet “Say You Won’t Let Go” jumps back up to #8, and Kodak Black’s “Tunnel Vision” jumps one spot to #10.The NewbiesIt’s almost summer, the season for Samba beats, bubbly BPMs and, naturally, the crowning of the ever-ambiguous Song of the Summer. Whatever Song of the Summer is measured by — sales? streams? product placements? — there’s a pretty good chance that DJ Khaled’s posse cut “I’m The One” will be a contender. Featuring Justin Bieber, Quavo, Chance the Rapper and Lil Wayne, the song is not only steeped in summer-y glee, but is also shaping up to be a top performer on the charts. “I’m the One” debuts this week at #11, but seeing as it’s already racking up close to 6 million weekly spins, expect it to rise fast.After the success of their Salt-N-Pepa-sampling breakout hit “Sex,” LA-based EDM trio Cheat Codes are back with “No Promises,” which features Demi Lovato. The song debuts at #62 this week, six spots ahead of DNCE’s “Kissing Strangers,” featuring Nicki Minaj. Coming in at #80 is Charlie Puth with “Attention” — off his upcoming sophomore album — followed by Brothers Osborne, who make an entrance and a political statement with “It Ain’t My Fault,” at #86.Behind “HUMBLE.” and “DNA,” “ELEMENT.” is among the top-performing tracks off of Kendrick Lamar’s “DAMN.”Debuting at #96 is Kendrick Lamar’s “ELEMENT.,” which is now seeing over 1 million spins weekly. It’s the fifth highest-performing track off DAMN., the Compton rapper’s fourth studio album. And after topping the Trendsetters Chart and making waves with his breakout single “My Sh**,” Bronx rapper A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie returns to the Top Spins Chart this week with “Drowning,” featuring Kodak Black. The artist born Artist Dubose is also seeing more than 50,000 artist station adds weekly on Pandora.The ClimbersAfter taking a twangy turn on Joanne, Lady Gaga’s remedy is apparently dance pop. “The Cure,” which Gaga debuted during her headlining set at Coachella, rises 28 spots this week — from #74 to #46— in its second week on the chart. Also making a big leap is Chris Brown’s “Privacy,” which hits #67 after a few weeks in the 90s.And Russ’ “Losin Control” may be a slow burn, it’s a searing one. While the song’s actually been around since November 2015, it’s seen a nice spike this week — 11 spots — after the release of his official debut album on May 5. Elsewhere, Train’s “Play That Song” jumps 14 spots, Rae Sremmurd’s “Swang” rises 12 spots, and Gucci Mane’s “Both” remix — featuring Drake and Lil Wayne — moves from #86 to #70.

title: Houston’s Christof Spieler on Selling the Vision for Better Transit — Remix Conference 2015
content: Houston’s Christof Spieler on Selling the Vision for Better Transit — Remix Conference 2015RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 19, 2015Video from our first Remix Conference in San Francisco on October 7, 2015.Christof Spieler, director of planning and Morris and a Houston Metro board member, discussed hooking the public on investing in transportation (especially during major system changes): “The impact of a transit line on a region cannot be measured in length or seen on a map….Nearly every city has an antiquated bus system that should be blown up and started over with.”His slides are also available here: Remix Conference 2015 — Christof Spieler, “Selling the Vision for Better Transit”

title: How to Build Equity, Opportunity, and Inclusion into Public Transit
content: How to Build Equity, Opportunity, and Inclusion into Public TransitRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 17, 2016Dr. Beverly Scott presents on equity, opportunity, and inclusion in this year’s Remix Conference keynote address.At Remix Conference last month, we were proud to host Dr. Beverly Scott, four-time transit agency CEO and transit-planning freethinker, as this year’s Remix keynote speaker. In case you missed it, here are the highlights:Dr. Scott outlined equity as fairness manifested in collective success. Equity is determined by results, not by opportunities. Only data can measure our progress toward these resultsIncreased investment alone does not mean it is translating to equitable outcomes. As transit planners, we must bring intent, focus, and urgency to the issue of equity and inclusivityTransit planners must understand that their work is critical to the goal of equity, no matter their rank or title at the organizationDemystifying what planners do isn’t part of the typical transit planner job description, real and continuous engagement with the community is a crucial part of implementationYou can watch Dr. Scott’s keynote presentation here:

title: Making Remix’s Settings Pane Work for Your Transit System
content: Making Remix’s Settings Pane Work for Your Transit SystemRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 19, 2015One of the most useful features of Remix is the ability to quickly cost out new or modified transit lines. There’s no magic that goes into our cost or revenue hour estimates — our modest, yet powerful settings pane allows you to adjust map-level variables that apply to all lines on any given Remix map.Here are the key elements of the settings pane:Costs: Toggle this on and off to display your transit resource need in terms of dollars or revenue hours. Below “estimate costs,” you’ll see three rows where you can input values:Costs per hourCosts per busCosts per mileTypically, Remix customers use an estimated per-hour cost. However, should you have a per-bus or per-mile cost, you can input that information. Remix will take all three factors into consideration. For example, if you know that your service costs $100 per hour and $0.50 per mile to operate, you could adjust the costs pane accordingly.Layover: Here, you can adjust the layover applied to all routes on a map. Choose between a percentage (setting layover as a certain percentage of the runtime) or a fixed number of minutes (added at the end of each end of a trip). Remix will select between the larger of the two on a route-by-route basis.Calendar: The calendar pane describes the time period over which Remix aggregates costs. For example, if a system has lines with weekday, Saturday, and Sunday services, Remix will aggregate the resource need of those lines across 255 weekdays, 55 Saturdays, and 55 Sundays.You can also use the calendar setting to determine specific information about your service. For example, you can set the calendar pane to “1” weekday in order to show a single weekday’s count of revenue hours.Schedule for New Lines: The schedule for new lines pane gives you the ability to set the default schedule for any new route created in Remix.While using the settings pane, don’t forget that your inputs apply to each line on a particular Remix map. To apply different settings to different lines, create them on separate maps.For more information on the settings pane, check out this video or test out different settings in Remix today.

title: Sketching Estimated Stop Locations In Remix
content: Sketching Estimated Stop Locations In RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 29, 2015Stops are a linchpin of Remix maps: Features like Jane are based on them, and they’re used for all our demographic calculations. And because transit service is only available where a vehicle stops, passengers are more invested in stops — where they can get on and get off — than in routes.Remix allows you to automatically add stops every .25 miles. By sketching a line and estimating stops at this distance, you can get a rough idea of a route’s demographics and the accessibility it will enable for your passengers, without needing to immediately finalize stop locations.Estimating stop locations only takes one click. To do so, draw a route. Double-click to finish. At the top of the right panel, click “…,” then click “Estimate stops.”Note that you can’t undo an estimation of stops. If you’d like to estimate stops on a route that already exists, we suggest doing so on a new copy. Estimating stop locations is best used on a new map to provide the base for a rough sketch.Has the ability to automatically add stops to routes made your workflow easier? Tell us about it!

title: What Is “Day-to-Day” Planning?
content: What Is “Day-to-Day” Planning?RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJul 17, 2017AVTA (Lancaster, CA) accelerates its planning time by exploring scenarios in real time during city council meetings.Planners Are Good JugglersOn a given day, a typical transit planner has many balls in the air. Service planning, public outreach, and liaising with elected officials — these all require a planner’s full attention to keep projects moving forward, and if any are dropped, it could mean a serious compromise for transit service in the community.Here are a few examples of how agencies are using Remix to keep the juggling act of day-to-day planning flowing smoothly.VIA (San Antonio, TX)VIA (San Antonio, TX) uses Remix to calculate more accurate runtimes for detour service.San Antonio takes “Remember the Alamo” seriously. Every year, San Antonians commemorate the famous battle with Fiesta, a 10-day celebration of parades, music, and street markets across the city.But for VIA, San Antonio’s transit agency, Fiesta means that half of the city’s routes need to be modified to ensure ongoing connections for its 150K daily riders.In the past, runtime estimates for detour routes were time-consuming and difficult to calculate, and headways weren’t always dependable. During Fiesta, drivers could never quite tell if they were on time, and riders never knew when the bus would come.With Remix, now VIA can sketch out their modified detour routes and quickly calculate much more accurate headways. With the new detour process in place, buses now come more dependably, and the planning team can enjoy the festivities with the rest of the city!Antelope Valley Transit Authority (Lancaster, CA)AVTA used to get bogged down with “what-if” questions during city council meetings. To answer board members’ questions, the AVTA team usually had to wait to crunch the numbers in the office, only to answer the question at the next meeting — one month later. The bottleneck had real effects on their plans, and the back and forth could add months to a project.Now with Remix, AVTA can explore scenarios during board meetings in real time. The team presents proposals designed in Remix on the screen, and the board can follow along, ask specific questions, and even suggest new alignments — all while seeing how each scenario affects operating costs, vehicle requirements, and demographics served.After one high-profile board meeting, one of AVTA’s planners said, “I can’t imagine ever going back to PowerPoint.”GoCary (Cary, NC)GoCary’s budget department in Cary, NC, used to find it time-consuming to draft high-level budgets for new projects. Worse, line items sometimes seemed unnecessary when taken out of context.With Remix, now the budget department can use visualizations to explain line items in meetings with other teams. They even release the budgets to the public for comment. GoCary says the best part is that budget estimates now only take a single day.For more examples of how to use Remix for day-to-day planning, you can read more customer stories, or just reach out at team@remix.com.

title: The United States API, and How Remix Uses It
content: The United States API, and How Remix Uses ItRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 10, 2015Our cofounder and CTO, Dan Getelman, originally published this post on Medium. We’re reposting it here.Open data is here, and is being used to help build businesses and help cities make better decisions. For years, technologists have been clamoring for governments to open up more of their data. It’s now happening. Cities of all sizes, from San Francisco to Asheville have open data portals filled with machine-readable data. Los Angeles, San Diego, and Philadelphia, among others, have even created executive Chief Data Officer positions that are responsible for opening data across departments. But, now that the data is out there, how is it actually getting used?I can tell you what we’re up to at Remix. We’re a quickly growing company that uses open data to help cities plan out better public transit. Here’s a couple of examples of how we take open data, and make it available for cities to make better decisions. I’ve also linked to sources and places you can find all the data we use, so be sure to follow the links! (Plug: If you’re interested in building great interfaces using open data, we’re hiring front-end engineers!)OpenStreetMap and Its EcosystemEverything in Remix is built on OpenStreetMap and different services and software packages in its ecosystem. In the photo above, all of the data you see in the map is coming from OpenStreetMap. We use Mapbox as a service to both generate the tiles that make up the map imagery, and to keep them up to date. OpenStreetMap has matured incredibly over the last couple of years, and offers us a number of advantages. First, the data is both accurate and easy to change. This is incredibly valuable to us, since it means that our customers immediately have correct data. And if it’s not quite right, it’s very easy to contribute those fixes back and quickly have them reflected in our product.One of the coolest advantages of OpenStreetMap, though, is in our routing. We’re able to use Valhalla, a project from Mapzen, to do dynamic routing. This lets us snap to roads as you draw routes. Being able to do that based on the easily updatable data I mentioned above is cool in itself, but there’s another advantage. OpenStreetMap actually has a tag for bus-only roads (psv, for “public service vehicle”), which means that we can use existing metadata to route bus lines over bus-only roads. This would be impossible with any other standard routing engine.Using GTFS To Show Planners Their Network Our users are transit planners — the city employees that decide where each bus goes, and how often it shows up. Without open data, often the best representation of their current transit system is the printed paper schedule. However, in recent years, agencies have begun publishing all of their schedule data in a format called the General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS). You can usually find this data on the transit agency’s website, or on aggregators like TransitFeeds.This data is output directly by the cities’ bus scheduling systems, and is far too granular to be directly useful by the planners. It also comes in a zip of CSVs, which isn’t easily digestable either. But it’s in a machine-readable format, and that has let us do a bit of magic to work backwards from the super-granular schedule back to their intent. We can take open data to give cities better ideas of the systems they’re running.Using the Census to Drive Better DecisionsI’d be remiss if I didn’t mention the U.S. Census, or “the original open data,” as my colleague Danny refers to it. The Census has been around since 1790, but can often be unwieldy to work with. We’ve been able to take this data, all of which is freely available, and place it right in front of transit planners when they’re making decisions.We were able to use some great existing open source tools, such as PostGIS, GDAL, Mapnik, and Tilestache to generate maps for a variety of factors, like population, jobs, people with low incomes, seniors, and more.We’re also able to take the high granularity of the Census data, and give an instant calculation of how many people are near a route, and their demographic characteristics. To get this kind of insight before, agencies would have had to go through an arduous analysis process. However, because the data is openly available, we’re able to build it right into the product and make it available at their fingertips.The Impact The important piece of this isn’t that open data is pretty, but that it gives city transit planners the information they need to help justify and make better decisions. Our team hears from planners from cities of all sizes, from Marvin in Sandusky to Max near Seattle, about how Remix has changed the way they make changes, and allowed them to more efficiently evaluate and justify alternatives. If any of this sounds interesting, we’re hiring!

title: Meet a Planner: Mark Kirstner of PART (Greensboro, NC)
content: Meet a Planner: Mark Kirstner of PART (Greensboro, NC)RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 6, 2015“I just kind of caught that transit bug,” says Mark Kirstner.Mark, AICP, began his career in the Guilford County planning department. He’s now the director of planning for the Piedmont Authority for Regional Transportation, a quasi-governmental agency that services North Carolina’s largely rural, low-density Piedmont Triad (which is home to 1.3 million people and spans 10 counties, plus the cities of Greensboro, Winston-Salem, and High Point). His desire to better unite transportation and land use planning — especially in regions like his, where transit is a lifeline for many residents commuting to jobs in other counties across the region — is front and center when he discusses his work.We spoke with Mark about how his department has begun to gather the kind of data necessary for route planning in the Triad and about how transportation can make places more equitable.Can you talk about what PART is working on and some of the challenges you face in your region?This past October, we started to take a look at all our routes, especially underperforming routes. It’s a recognition that there’s a whole lot more data out there that we can use for analysis. In the past, it was just some raw commuter data, like, 15,000 people are going from this county to the next county. We started developing a methodology late last year because our routes are very unique. They don’t fit the urban fixed-route patterns in terms of frequency, and they’re not circular routes or anything like that. We weren’t finding a lot of information or data in the research world about how if you increase your frequencies — some of ours were four hours, to two hours — what that would mean to ridership.One of the first things we did was a survey of folks using our park-and-rides to see how far they were driving to see if we could get an average. If we drew a 10-minute circle around this lot, how many people would that be? That progressed to using our travel demand model and socioeconomic data to see how many people might be living or working somewhere, then to the LEHD data on jobs and employment. We’ve been refining that since we started down that road. Remix makes that manual process fairly automatic. We had the big super-spreadsheet that our finance department had done about two years ago, which gave us some real insight into each route and what it was costing. That was the basic method as short as a year and a half ago: We pay our contractor this, our fuel costs are this, we put it in Google Earth to get an estimate of how long the route is, then run it and see what happens. Remix really helps with visualization and being able to test out different route scenarios on the fly.How else has technology enabled your work?We started just by looking at what we are calling catchment areas, or geographic zones related to our transit service. We looked at how many people were within a 10-minute drive of the park-and-ride lot and how many people live and worked in a service corridor. We are also using a five-minute walk zones around bus stops and the park-and-ride lots since you can walk up and get on the bus there, too. We use the socioeconomic data in the travel demand model and look at the people and employment in the geographies we create. We even break the employment into job clusters. Then, we started using LEHD data to visualize more people’s movements, or where they worked and where they lived. That, again, helped define some service areas that we had not had before. Now, we’re using our own geographies to analyze the LEHD data.How did connecting land use and transit planning become interesting to you?I worked first in the county planning department doing parks planning, traditional zoning and subdivisions, small-area plans. Due to an odd set of circumstances, I got sent down to the county’s community transportation system, which is the county’s demand-response transit system for medical and senior service trips. I just kind of caught that transit bug and really found it gratifying to go home every day and say we provided trips to 600 people, to get to a medical appointment or a senior center. While planning itself was gratifying, here I could see the results of my work on a daily basis.Having the land-use background when I got to the transit world, I quickly learned that people have to be able to access whatever the transit infrastructure is, and that access is really distance-based, so your land use patterns really impact an individual’s access to transit. You easily see that you’re a low-density area that can’t be truly supportive of transit, but you know that there are great benefits in terms of people saving money; having more compact, walkable urban areas and neighborhoods; and having access to jobs.I’ve been interested in transportation equity lately and I firmly believe that enhanced transit systems can help solve poverty issues. So many things that we do to help people in need don’t really help bring them out of poverty. This goes back to the amount of money that might be needed for a car when you include the total cost. If there’s some way that you can reduce people’s transportation costs by five percent, that’s that much more money in their pocket that provides some long-term stability in terms of more income, food, housing. One thing that cities do is transportation, of which transit is part of. Therefore, that is the best way cities can help with poverty.It took a long time to realize as a land-use planner how little control you do have. I think that here, especially, the market, the development community, and the actual property owners determine so much. Instead of land-use planning, it’s land-use management. When parcels do get developed, is it the best fit for the whole community? There’s that piece of the challenge but, on the flipside, while a city might not be able to totally control where housing or jobs go, it does control its transportation infrastructure, whether highways or public transit. I think cities often spend too much time on other things and not enough on public transit.

title: What’s New in Remix Scheduling?
content: What’s New in Remix Scheduling?RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 14, 2017Deadhead runtimes are now editable for each deadhead trip.More Flexibility Means More ControlWe recently shipped four new features to help you customize your experience within Remix Scheduling. Here’s a summary of how these new features give you more control over the schedules you build in Remix.1. Editable Deadhead RuntimesA deadhead is a non-revenue trip that a vehicle takes as part of its fixed route service. Deadheads include pull-ins and pull-outs to/from the garage as well as driving between different locations in the field in between revenue trips.Now you can directly edit these estimates to reflect the time that your agency actually allocates to the deadhead. To do so, simply right-click the deadhead task in the block chart. In the context menu that appears, simply click on the old value and type something new over it.Deadheads with user-entered durations have a gray background.This modifies the deadhead matrix stored in Remix’s backend, so the update will apply to all the other deadheads that have the same start and end location. Note that this won’t update deadheads in the reverse direction, so they need to be edited separately.When a map is copied, the deadhead matrix is copied with it, so all deadhead times will be the same as those in the original map.2. Customizable Block and Run NamesBlock and run names are now fully customizable.Previously, blocks and runs had no identifiers, they simply had a number reflecting their position in the current sort order.This could cause trouble when you wanted to keep track of an individual block or run. Every time you’d sort by a different column, the names would change.Now, block and run IDs stay the same even when they change position in the list, and you can edit them. Now you can have naming schemes for your blocks and runs, helping to keep schedulers and operators on the same page about what work it includes.The names you give blocks and runs show up in the Remix Excel export as well as in the paddles.3. Defining Garage LocationsRemix now allows you to define the location of your garage. To do so, simply right-click on a location on a map and pick “Garage” in the dropdown. Give it a name and then hit “Create.”Remix now allows you to define the location of your garage.Remix still currently only supports a single garage per map.4. Defining Relief PointsRemix now allows you to define the stops where operators can be relieved. To do so, simply right-click on the stop, and click to set “Relief point” to “yes.”Remix now allows you to define the stops where operators can be relieved.Relief points automatically default to “Meal break points”, locations where operators can take breaks after handing over the bus to another operator. To turn this off, set “Meal break point” to “no.”Continuous ImprovementsWe ship improvements for the Remix platform whenever they’re ready, so you always have the most recent version of Remix. To stay up to date on recent changes, you can follow along here, or always feel free to reach out to your customer success manager.

title: From Transit Planning to Tech
content: From Transit Planning to TechRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJul 29, 2015A few words from Paul Supawanich, our Director of Customer SuccessThis June, I made a major professional shift from transportation consulting to product. This was a relatively big decision in my life, but it comes grounded in history. Flashback to 2006, despite graduating from a university with “technology” in its name, I decided to take a step in a another and pursue what I thought then to be more of a “brick and mortar” field of study: city planning. At the time, I personally felt an interest to learn more about the ability to influence cities and an element of life that impacts all of us: transportation, with a specific interest in public transportation.Almost everyone spends a significant portion of their life commuting between point A and point B, and I had an interest in making that time healthier, more productive, and more enjoyable. As a transit consultant for six years, I had the opportunity to comprehensively understand the challenges that cities and transit agencies face in their efforts to improve. While there are many elements that influence organizational decision making, there is one in common: The desire for data driven decisions. Yet there continued to be lack of staff-level solutions available to process, analyze and effectively communicate this information, in real-time. Alternatively, decision making for the transit-riding public has largely benefited from real-time arrival data based on GTFS feeds. However, internally, public transportation agencies lack similarly effective tools. I witnessed this weakness across many transit planning characteristics including on-time performance, fare collection, and service planning.Visually uninspiring and unsharable spreadsheets are the backbone of transit service planning exercises across the nation.When I first heard about Remix (at that time Transitmix), I was captivated by its ability to visualize tradeoffs in planning transit. While a simple concept, this is a critically important step in enabling a community understand difficult city decisions in delivering transportation. Furthermore, it provides planners the ability to concisely synthesize some of the most effusive data in transit planning in a matter of seconds. If transit planning is a matter of art and science, Remix is advancing the science saving transit agencies valuable time and resources. These elements excited excited me the most. While the consumer transportation industry has certainly been “disrupted” in the last few years, the same had yet to happen for transit planning. Microsoft Excel, in combination with various spatial software packages continued to ruled the day and I believed there had to be better. Thus, I made the decision to come back to work for a technology start-up whose primary focus is public transit and whose long-term goal is to help plan better transit through software. Through outstanding software, I believe we can have an critically important positive impact for public transportation by putting more powerful tools in the hands of local planners.Within seconds, we’ve imported Albany, NY’s existing route network and immediately evaluate transit alternatives, with cost information and demographic data to visually guide our thought processUnlike many other transit software packages focused on implementation, we wanted to focus our software at the top, the vision. Our software enables further collaboration and experimentation which helps our customers feel confident that they’ve arrived at the best solutions for their plans. Beyond the features and benefits that Remix offers today, it opens the door for a new world of opportunities: powerful software that fits the need and workflow for transit planning and we have only begun. We are currently adding features every week with a primary focus on making our product even better. In our first six months, we’ve gained the trust of over 50 transit agencies around the country who are helping us build the tools to power better transit. I’m excited about whats to come and believe it’s time for transit planning to enjoy the benefits of today’s latest technology. For more on our story, visit us at getremix.com.

title: Micheaux’s ‘Within Our Gates’ Live Remix By DJ Spooky At 2016 ImageNation Festival In Harlem
content: Micheaux’s ‘Within Our Gates’ Live Remix By DJ Spooky At 2016 ImageNation Festival In HarlemHarlemWorldMagazineBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJul 13, 2016The folks at the 2016 ImageNation Outdoors Film & Music Festival In Harlem have done it again with another great film series that started in June, and continues until August 2016.What’s up next? Check out their latest offering:Sunday, July 17, 2016, at St. Nicholas Park, Harlem, St. Nicholas Ave & 135th Street., with the Historic Harlem Parks Film FestivalWithin Our Gates Live Remix by DJ Spooky AKA Paul MillerDirected by Oscar Micheaux, 79 Min., USAFeatured on the new PIONEERS OF AFRICAN-AMERICAN CINEMA DVD, Oscar Micheaux’s Within Our Gates is the earliest surviving feature film by an African-American director. This drama tells the story of Sylvia Landry who attempts to raise money for an elementary school to serve the black community. In this film, Micheaux’s staging of a lynching is startling in its bluntness and speaks to the director’s fearlessness and willingness to address taboo subject matter. Within Our Gates is a landmark achievement of independent film and one of the cornerstones of the forthcoming DVD/Blu-ray series Pioneers of African-American Cinema, from Kino Classics. The film will be released with a New musical score composed by Paul D. Miller, aka DJ Spooky.Live Music: DJ Spooky AKA Paul MillerPaul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky is a composer, multimedia artist and writer whose work immerses audiences in a blend of genres, global culture, and environmental and social issues. Miller has collaborated with a vast array of recording artists, ranging from Metallica to Chuck D; Steve Reich to Yoko Ono. His written work has been published by The Village Voice, The Source, and Artforum, among others, and he is the Editor of Origin Magazine. Miller’s art has appeared in the Whitney Biennial; The Venice Biennial for Architecture; the Ludwig Museum in Cologne; Kunsthalle, Vienna; The Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, the Miami/Art Basel fair, and many other museums and galleries. Miller was the first Artist in Residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he premiered his work “A Civil War Symphony” in 2013.PIONEERS will be released by Kino Classics on July 26, 2016. title: Better Peak Bus Counts
content: Better Peak Bus CountsRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 25, 2016An agency’s peak bus count represents the maximum number of vehicles in service during the busiest time of operation. Often, this is during morning or evening commute periods where most people are traveling to and from work and service levels are highest.Based on customer feedback, we have worked to improve our bus estimation algorithms to more accurately reflect the systemwide peak bus count.Here’s what’s different: In the past, Remix independently determined each route’s peak bus count and then summed those peaks to determine the systemwide total. In the future, Remix will determine the peak number of buses required, systemwide, by time of day.Example: In the diagram below, there are two routes. Route 1 operates in the AM and PM peak only. Route 2 operates the highest level of service midday. The peak of Routes 1 and 2 both are five. The old method determined a peak bus count of 10. However, the new method takes into consideration that the peak bus levels for these two routes are not running at the same time. Thus, the actual peak is 7, which occurs both in the AM an PM service periods.New peak bus counting should be more accurate by taking into consideration bus peaks, by route, by time of day.Next time you login to Remix, you’ll be able to see the peak bus counts at the individual line leveland at the systemwide level (time of the day is represented by the vertical bars). As a result, you may see slightly lower systemwide peak bus counts as compared to before.This new bus counting methodology will rollout on Friday, January 29th. To view, simply roll your cursor over the number of buses, and this information will appear.This is just one of many exciting updates that will be rolling out this spring. Keep checking our blog for additional new features and as always, let us know if you have questions.

title: How to Break Away From the Street Grid
content: How to Break Away From the Street GridRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 24, 2015When drawing a route in Remix, the line will automatically adhere to the most optimal route.Mapzen’s Valhalla, our routing engine, makes this possible. To determine these optimal routes, Valhalla weighs the cost of factors like distance and time. It also rolls in bus access and one-way streets.Sometimes, that results in squiggly lines:These squiggles can be largely smoothed out by dragging the points you’ve placed as stops. But, if you’d like your route to go somewhere off the street grid — into a shopping center to turn around, for instance — you can use our “shift to fly” feature.Simply press shift and continue drawing your route. Shift to fly enables you to add to your route a section that does not conform with the street grid.For more details about drawing routes and shift to fly, check out our training videos or give it a try in Remix!

title: From the Field: Top Trends from the CA Transit Conference
content: From the Field: Top Trends from the CA Transit ConferenceRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 30, 2015Last week, we had a chance to be part of the California Transit Association’s 50th Conference and Expo in Pasadena, CA. CalTransit is one of two major California-specific transit conferences (the other being CalACT). Foothill Transit (A Remix customer) played local host and provided us an incredible experience in Pasadena (including a trip to the Rose Bowl)There were plenty of interesting topics and sessions. Yet, a key theme heard repeatedly across the three-day event is that technology is going to fundamentally change the industry and we should start preparing for that change. Amen. Based on my time in Pasadena, here’s are my five technology-based takeaways moving the needle in the transit industry.1) Electric Buses Like any transit aficionado, I was eager to walk into the expo to see the lineup of new transit buses with that new car smell. But this year, half of the shiny new 40 footers were not powered by diesel, or even natural gas, but they were electric. Battery-toting, quiet as night, emission-free electric 40' buses.Back in 2010, Foothill Transit was on the bleeding edge of this industry and ventured alone into this space. But today, they’re joined by other agencies in California (Antelope Valley Transportation Authority), and a few others around the country.Battery technology has advanced at a rapid pace, making it more affordable and more reliable than in the past and bus vendors are in an proverbial showdown to try to win over agencies looking to make the switch. With additional options to choose from and more agencies with electric vehicle experience, I think we’ll be seeing many more on the streets in the future.2) Private Ridesourcing It’s nearly impossible to sit in any transit session at any conference without word “Uber” being uttered at least once. The dialogue around ridesourcing companies at CalTransit carried similar tones, but also invoked interesting discussions about the role that public/private partnerships play in transportation service delivery. There still is a notion from many that these companies are competitors. But companies like Lyft are taking the tack that we’re all friends battling a larger opponent of single occupancy vehicle trips.Personally, I imagine a time in the future where public agencies truly could leverage these companies (beyond linking to them in an app) as one of their methods of providing mobility (in addition to other items in the “mobility toolkit” such as buses, bikeshare, and carshare). Some of these options may be operated directly while others are simply a vendor underneath the transit agency’s umbrella.Also, if you’re into this type of thing you might be interested to know that for the very first time, Uber and Lyft are partnering (ala, sharing data) with the National Resource Defense Council and UC Berkeley to produce a study on the environmental impacts of these types of ridesourcing services.3) Microtransit To me, “microtransit” is a word that captures the types of publicly accessible transportation that fall between a 40' bus and a taxi. This could be jitneys, shared-ride vans (Bridj, Chariot), and even shared-ride ridesourcing platforms like UberPool and Lyft Line.I had the opportunity to speak on this topic on Wednesday of the conference. One of the things that stands out to me is the fact there are more new providers in this space in the past two years versus the past twenty. The services that I mention above (any many others) are filling an important niche of transportation between fixed-route transit (low cost, potential longer travel time) and taking a taxi (higher cost, lower travel time), or your own personal vehicle. It’s not just private companies jumping into this space, public transit agencies such as VTA in San Jose, and Cherriots in Salem, OR are getting into the game. Private vendors are supporting public sector agencies by providing the technology foundation for these types of on-demand, publicly dispatched services. (see RideCell, DoubleMap, and Transloc) I think we’ll certainly see more of this to come in the future. For more information on Microtransit, check out this CityLab article.4) Driverless Technology I cringe when I hear people say that driverless cars are going to solve all of our problems. They certainly will solve some but will surely introduce others. I won’t attempt to speculate on all of the topics where driverless cars will make an impact. But we can be certain that transportation habits, vehicle ownership trends, and the built form of our cities will all be affected. The question that remains is when will this change come? During the conference, Tony Seba from Stanford University made a compelling case that historical trends show that game-changing technologies are adopted at a much faster rate than is predicted by even the best experts. Using examples of the adoption of cell phones and even the personal computer provided examples of market saturation far faster than any prediction of the time. Given the way things are going, we very well may expect the same with driverless vehicles and even driverless buses.Maybe the future is already here, driverless buses are slated to be in-service in San Ramon, CA in 2016.5) Better Biking and Walking Infrastructure Ok, so this wasn’t one of the themes from the conference, but I wish it would have been. The conference itself was held in Downtown Pasadena, a remarkably walkable place in LA standards and a place where you can imagine a pleasant walk or bike ride to catch the Metro Gold Line or other transit services. However, from my own experience, I know this sadly is not the case across much of California.Understandably, transit agencies can’t take on all of the responsibility in their jurisdictions for creating safer places to walk and bike (how every transit trip starts and ends). However, they perhaps can place additional pressure on their local jurisdictions for complete streets ordinances, plans, or pilot projects to take action. Places where it’s easier to walk and bike makes it easier to ride transit. Furthermore, when people feel safe and comfortable walking to catch the train or bus, transit agencies may be able to reduce time-consuming deviations or excessive bus stop placement that are sometimes used to compensate for a substandard pedestrian network.Safe walking and and biking isn’t really technologically advanced, but I think this is an important point. Technology has its place as a tool to help us find better solutions, but often, it’s not the solution itself. Sometimes the simple fixes (sidewalks, safe crossings, good multimodal transportation policy) are the best ways to improve transit.For more up-to-date musing from the road, follow me at @tweetsupa.

title: How to View Nearby Transit Lines in Remix
content: How to View Nearby Transit Lines in RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 14, 2015Remix has made its first foray into right-clicking with our new “Nearby lines” feature. “Nearby lines” is an easy way to check if there are multiple transit lines on a specific street.To use it, right-click on a map. title: Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies — The Warren Ellis Gun Machine remix
content: Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies — The Warren Ellis Gun Machine remixRev Dan CattBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingFeb 17, 2017So I stripped the DRM off Warren Ellis’s Gun Machine, crunched the text and threw it into the Markov Chain engine. You can see the results here: revdancatt.github.io/CAT782-remixing-ellisAs I already have the code set up pretty well for consuming new text it’s fun to put different things in and see what comes out. I promise I’ll stick the code up on github once I’ve cleaned it up a bit more. In the meantime this is all heading somewhere, kinda.Something I found interesting is that it seems easier to find short snappy tweetable results from Sk1n (that I’ve remixed previously) than Gun Machine. Which of course isn’t a measure of quality, more that Gun Machine’s story whips along at a frenetic pace (and is wonderful) the sentences feel like good solid strongly bonded elements. Meanwhile in Channel Sk1n and other books by Jeff Noon the sentences feel faster but looser, more easily sampled, looped, and remixed.That’s pretty hand wavy, let’s try this instead…It’s a bit like Gun Machine is the melody and bassline, while Channel Sk1n is the samples, synth stabs and one shots. Lord knows what would happen if I threw them together, actually I should probably try that.The idea of using the Markov Chains is to mix things up. A remix of Gun Machine will use just the words written by Ellis and not a single new one. These tiny word atoms also remain in roughly the order Ellis put them in, but sometimes new structures similar in style and tone to the original are formed. My task is to then have a root around the output looking for these small, newly formed gems.I’m a pretty terrible writer and so turn to code to attempt to skirt around that, by using other people’s work and algorithms to somehow generate something new. This approach works when the samplers are talented (i.e. the Beastie Boys) and not so much when they aren’t (i.e. me). It’s like I’m looking for cheats and shortcuts, you never know maybe I’ll learn something in the process.One of these cheats or “inspiration tools” I’ve played with is the N+7 algorithm. You take each noun, find it in the dictionary, look at the 7th noun after that one and replace the first noun with the new one.Here’s an example of a straight up Markov mix from Gun Machine…“Fifteen minutes later, he threw it into her eyes, seemed to take out his phone and answered it with lightning pingback. As I’ve been ordered to conduct this investigation, without a clue that his leanness was turning a blind eye to calculate her alertness.”Here it is again in N+7“Fifteen misapprehensions later, he threw it into her eye-openers, seemed to take out his photocopy and answered it with lilt pingback. As I’ve been ordered to confederacy this invite, without a coach-and-four that his leanness was turnstile a blizzard eye-opener to calculate her alertness.”We’ve stepped out of the Gun Machine world, new words are coming in cross contaminating and building different bonds to the original. I’m not suggesting any of this is new, but it is new for me.N+15 with a small dictionary gives us this:“Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies, seemed to take out his pillar and answered it with lightning pingback. As I’ve been ordered to consequence this jail, without a collapse that his leanness was turning a blind fantasy to calculate her alertness.”Novel remixing on the Grid.I’ve been playing a lot with MPC-type sample/beat pads, grids of soft pads that light up and play samples as you hit/tap them… I mean obviously there’s a lot more to it than that and I’m as bad at creating music as I am writing.Music tools are all over the place, word tools though really not so much. I know there are experiments out there — but not many. In my ideal world there’d be more for words, even better my as yet unwritten novel remixing tool would exist, more on that in a moment.The problem with taking a whole novel and shuffling the words around is the narrative gets chopped up too. The characters are still there, Nola Blue, Alice (both of them[1]) and Tallow, but they can easily jump from one scene to the next — wormholes through the pages from front to back, and back again. Time is lost and the narrative confused.But, say I want to make a new novel by remixing from several sources. I take five books, Gun Machine, Channel Sk1n, Automated Alice, Alice in Wonderland and The Big Sleep. Instead of taking all the text and throwing it into a bucket I divide each into roughly equal chapters and just mix those up. More than that though, to create a new Chapter 2, I take all the words from the original Chapter twos [2] and then add the words from the chapters each side of them, one and three. It looks like this……So I’m remixing the originals, but in a more controlled fashion. The narrative of the remix will still kind of follow the narrative of the original books, just. We won’t be throwing something in from the end of one book into the start of another. New characters will get introduced at roughly the same time, and the story will shift gradually from the start to the end.A quick flashback to “The Kibin Magic Kettle Experiment”But I’m still not a writer, so now over to crowd sourcing. Last year I tried an experiment, it was terrible and didn’t work, for reason I’ll get into in a moment.I wanted to see if I could use proofreading sites that promise to fix your copy and so on (although now I think I would try paying someone on Fiverr: I will meticulously proofread and edit 1500 words of English text for $5 which is an option just to see what happens) to play Chinese Whispers on a story.As a quirk of Kibin quickly iterating over business models I snagged a year’s subscriptions worth of proofreading, I could put one article into their system at a time which had a turn around of 24–48 hours. I figured much like photocopying an image and putting that back through the copying machine I could end up with something different after shoving a story through the machine 100 times.I took this story: The Magic Kettle (github) and mangled it up via Google Translate a couple of times — the end result still had the main narrative but the grammar and everything else was pretty shot, but not so much that it no longer made any sense though.I wondered if the story would get restored close to its original source, or if it’d wonder off on tangents and become something else through the process of other people’s proofreading personality and bias. I set myself a couple of quick rules, well one mainly — I’d accept all suggested corrections.The experiment didn’t go well. Not because of the proofreading — the first couple of editors cleaned the story up fairly well, the third took all the life out of it and the fourth put some back in — but rather because the Kibin site made it hard to accept the suggestions. On top of that, I thought GitHub would be a good place to put the results so people would be able to use the tools there to see the differences (diffs) between version.The combination of Kibin usability, GitHub not really doing large blocks of text well[3] and the story obviously just going round in circles after the 4th edit[4] all made me feel that the effort I would have to put in wasn’t going to be worth it.I’d probably do things slightly different if I was going to do it again now.Pulling it all together.I like the idea of “Making Things Fast", however I seem to end up making things slowly — which is why I’ve decided just to say “to hell with it” and write up projects as I go along.I’m going to play with the idea of pulling text into a remixing machine in the same way you can with audio tools. Until I can throw, say, 5 books into the new words-machine, chop them up into chunks and specify which chunks to remix together, much like the diagram I drew above.I’ll then get the computer to generate version after version after version which I’ll review and somehow attempt to pick the “best” bits. See if there’s any hope for the narrative or, you know, anything usable in there at all.If the approach yields useful prose, then maybe I can string it all together and take it to the proofreading site, Mechanical Turk and/or Fiverr. Human machines to force a bit of grammar and structure, and possibly find out if people can spot patterns and make sense of the garbled output. People are supposed to be good at that, right?Then I’ll write about it some more.And probably get it printed and bound, because that makes it real.
