“Everything is a Remix” — Billy Wilder styleScott MyersBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 25, 2015On Sundays, I’ve been taking a leisurely tour through the wonderful book “Conversations with Wilder” which captures a series of talks between filmmaker Cameron Crowe (Say Anything, Singles, Almost Famous, Jerry Maguire) and writer-director Billy Wilder (Double Indemnity, Sunset Blvd., Ace in the Hole, Stalag 17, Witness for the Prosecution).The last two posts just so happen to put a spotlight on one aspect of Wilder’s creative process: He took story ideas from preexisting movies.If you go here, you can read about how Wilder’s inspiration for The Apartment derived from the 1945 movie Brief Encounter.If you go here, you can see how Wilder took a good story concept from what he called an “absolutely terrible” movie Fanfare of Love (1932) and used that as the basis for Some Like It Hot.In both cases, Wilder put his own creative stamp on the source material.In terms of Brief Encounter, this is what Wilder had to say:The origin of The Apartment was my seeing the very fine picture by David Lean, Brief Encounter [1945]. It was the story of a man who is having an affair with a married woman and comes by train to London. They go to the apartment of a friend of his. I saw it and I said, “What about the guy who has to crawl into the warm bed…?” That’s an interesting character. Then I put that down, and put down some other things in my notebook. The hero of that thing was the guy who endured this, who was introduced to it all by a lie. One guy in his company needed to change his clothes, he said, and used the apartment…and that was it.Wilder switched points of narrative perspective. He wasn’t interested in either party having the affair, rather what caught his creative imagination was the poor guy whose apartment the couple was using to conduct their tryst.Likewise with Fanfare of Love, a German movie, Wilder said this:The genesis of the idea was a very low-budget, very third-class German picture [Fanfares of Love, 1932] where two guys who need a job go into blackface to get into a band…they also dress up to go into a female band. But there was not one other thing that came from this terrible picture. We had to find, I thought, the key to why they go into that band and what keeps them there. If the gangsters who are chasing them see them as women, only as women, then…once they are seen as men, they are dead. It’s life and death. They cannot come out into the open. It’s a question of life and death. That triggered everything. So we began to have a picture.Again Wilder put his stamp on an existing story conceit — guys dressed as women musicians — by elevating the stakes into a life or death situation.Pondering the fact that Wilder, my favorite filmmaker of all time, openly admitted to in effect cribbing story ideas from other movies led me to a series of posts I did between 2010–2012, tracking the evolution of what became a 4-part video series called “Everything is a Remix” from Kirby Ferguson. Here are those four videos:Part 1: The Song Remains the SamePart 2: Remix Inc.Part 3: Elements of CreativityPart 4: System FailureTakeaways? Well, the first thing is to remind ourselves everything has basically been done before. Any time we come up with a story concept, we are, whether we know it or not, standing on the shoulders of ideas similar to the ones which emerge into our consciousness.The second thing is this: That reality just so happens to fit into Hollywood’s longstanding business ethos — similar but different. They prefer projects which are similar to films or TV series which have already proved to be successful, yet different enough to stand on their own two creative feet.Clearly Wilder found the sweet ‘similar but different’ spot with both Some Like It Hot and The Apartment. There’s a lesson there for all of us which I’d like to apply when we reach the end of our current classic 1950’s movies, maybe try a bit of Wilder brainstorming. Look for that in a few days.Personally I love the idea of looking at movies with great concepts poorly executed, then ‘rescuing’ them with a new treatment. The Bitter Script Reader just tweeted something on this yesterday:What other inferior movies with great story concepts can you think of to rescue from the trash heap? Let’s see if we can come up with a list of them, movies that should be remade, only better, rather than great movies which should not be remade if only to make a buck.Comment Archive

“Prove that people want to remix curriculum.”Laura HilligerBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 13, 2015Easier said than done. Back in the day, my amazing colleague Jess Klein made an epic PDF laying out a lesson plan for what was then known as Hackasaurus. People who teach started using it left and right, and when I saw it for the first time I thought “Holy moly that looks like a fun bit of curriculum.” But I didn’t need all of it. I only needed pieces and parts (many of which, BTW, are baked in, remixed and modified within Webmaker Teaching Kits), and so I started to think about the models we use when we make curriculum. The old smelly models that didn’t evolve as technology evolved.A map of all the resources and their connections to an initial Teaching KitI’ve always thought the models and systems could be better, so several years ago I started working on an educational model that centered on the idea that educators ALWAYS remix. I thought that if the model was clear, we could tackle the problems of OERs while making new curriculum to #TeachTheWeb. Fast forward about five years and the OER (open educational resources) movement has become something that is well known within the open and the educational communities. But people are still publishing their resources in ways that make remix hard, and as a result we edunerds tend to remix on the fly.We implemented the model in HTML, creating overview pages that were separate from activities. The idea was to separate all the pieces and parts of curriculum — the learning objectives, the assessment criteria, the activities, the overviews — so that any one individual part could be remixed into a new bit of curriculum. We tried to lay this model out using the mechanics of the web to make the modularity and remixability clear, but we began to realize that“No one remixes the HTML. It’s too high bar.”So now, I’m trying to figure out how we can collect those on the fly remixes and get educators to understand how important their ideas and feedback is when it comes to learning materials. What works? What doesn’t work? How did someone remix context?I think that Webmaker could become the clearinghouse for Web Literacy OERs, and to do so, I think remixability is key. I still think the model is solid, but we haven’t gotten to a place where remixing curriculum is common place. This post begins to explore WHY.The Problems of OERs1. Open Licenses are Confusing and Attribution is Hard“confusion over copyright, fair use, and Creative Commons is one of things that makes many educators hesitant about adopting any new resources, licensing be damned.” — Audrey Watters“Often resources using more open licenses incorporate or refer to media that are made available using a more restrictive license.” (Tel Amiel 2013)In education there is “…still a limited understanding of how to move beyond some of the encumbrances — specifically with regard to reusing others’ content as well as more complex reuse behaviors that lead to new configurations of existing content” (Petrides et al., 2008, p. 352). (Tel Amiel 2013)Users need to be able to contextualize credit depending on how they’ve used a resource.Is the resource BY someone who used an open license or is the user under Fair Use?Is the resource a light edit of someone else’s?Was the resource based on or inspired by someone else’s?2. Users don’t have time to make the required effort“Faculty consistently listed the time and effort to find and evaluate open educational resources as the most important barriers to adoption.” (Open the Curriculum 2014)“Existing educational sites and repositories contribute to this concern. Most are focused on the distribution and dissemination of resources and provided little guidance or tools for those who wish to make revisions or remix existing resources.” (Tel Amiel 2013)Staff (anywhere) rarely have the time to review all the resources submitted. We build software and communities though, so how can automation or, much more importantly, social evaluation make it easy for users to find quality curriculum?3. There are technical barriers to remix“When presenting OER development and use, many of the restrictions derived from our working scenario came to the forefront. In many cases, the source guides assumed a reader with substantial access to computer-based resources. “ (Tel Amiel 2013)“The process of remix is usually associated with four steps: finding, relating, creating, and sharing resources…Many of the online portals, which contain more openly licensed resources either do not have alternative language interfaces or metadata, which impacts both finding and sharing resources in these sites.” (Tel Amiel 2013)We have to design mobile-first and keep our need for localization at the forefront. We know this, but we also need to find more ways for lo-fi, no-fi communities to share their offline remixes (e.g. a couple of community managers does not a stable system make).Towards SolutionsCreative Commons licensing table and an early Mozilla Drumbeat project that aimed to make attribution easy.Make licensing and attribution easy, embedded. I’ll leave it to the amazing devs and designers to figure out what exactly that means, but building this into our tools from the onset is a way to encourage remix at all levels (both in learner focused and mentor focused content).“Reuse is perhaps reminiscent of the rhetoric around learning objects as they were presented as blocks of media that could be reused and assembled for different contexts, a metaphor that did not hold in practice (Fulantelli et al., 2008; Gunn et al., 2005).”Make remixability & modularity obvious and lean into social evaluation. This is as much about presentation as it is about functionality. We are missing context around our educational model. We’re starting to do that with the Club curriculum, where we are building resources on how to remix as well as giving examples of why and when and how we’ve remixed.Build the thing that makes it easy for others to build their thing (no matter what device they have). As we build features for our communities, continuing to encourage open interaction is essential to changing the landscape of OERs (and open in general). What are the ways in which we can utilize existing systems to encourage remixable curriculum? We’ve thought on this before…Leave me comments and check out the Bibliography:Watters, A. (2012). What Do We Mean By “Open”? http://hackeducation.com/2012/09/18/define-open/McEneaney, J. E. (2000). Learning on the Web: A Content Literacy PerspectiveAmiel, Tel (2013). Identifying Barriers to the Remix of Translated Open Educational Resources http://www.irrodl.org/index.php/irrodl/article/view/1351/2428Allan, E. and Seaman, J. (2014). Opening the Curriculum: Open Educational Resources in U.S. Higher Education, 2014 http://www.onlinelearningsurvey.com/reports/openingthecurriculum2014.pdfOriginally published at www.zythepsary.com on January 13, 2015.

title: Transit Innovations in Texas and Beyond, With Remix
content: Transit Innovations in Texas and Beyond, With RemixRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 8, 2015One of my favorite parts of my role at Remix is hearing what’s going on across the transportation sector. In October, I took a quick tour of Texas to participate in two national transportation conferences, Railvolution and NACTO’s Designing Cities conference. Here are a few highlights from each:Railvolution (Dallas, TX) This cheekily named conference has its origins in Portland, OR and has traditionally focused on light rail projects and transit-oriented development. However, in recent years, conference organizers have expanded the focus to “Building Livable Communities with Transit,” regardless of mode. The conference program reflected this with a cross-section of sessions and mobile workshops ranging from transit’s role in housing affordability, to food access, and to how agencies are leveraging new partnerships to expand their own networks. In addition, DART, the host agency, showed off its brand-new light rail extension to DFW Airport and its mobile app (which includes fare payment and the ability to hail a rideshare service).Shared-use mobility, which is taking a prominent seat at many transportation and transit conferences nationwide, was a hot topic at Railvolution, too:Shared-use mobility encompasses all means of transportation that facilitate “sharing,” such as bikeshare, carshare (peer-to-peer, or Zipcar-traditional), and has been a catch-all for ride-hailing companies such as Lyft and Uber. To learn more, check out the Shared Use Mobility Center.I was also excited to hear some of Remix’s partners share stories of their innovative work. Here’s a snippet from a presentation from Lane Transit District in Eugene, Oregon.We also had the opportunity to share what we’re doing at Remix! Our own Claudia Preciado took the stage at Railvolution’s Pecha Kucha Slam (20 slides, 20 seconds each). We heard some great stories from the presenters, and there was even an incredible transit-themed music video.NACTO Designing Cities (Austin, TX) In a previous life, I worked to promote better street design for pedestrians, cyclists, and transit. The North American City Transportation Officials group is at the forefront of this work. Previous NACTO initiatives include the Urban Bikeway Design Guide and Urban Street Design Guide. While what NACTO does is not always focused on transit directly, its work helps to create an underlying network enabling people to safely access public transportation by foot, bicycle, bikeshare, carsharing, or any other non-single occupancy vehicle modes.This year’s conference program included a surprise: a preview of the Transit Street Design Guide, a best-practice guide for city transportation and public works departments to improve the experience of using transit. It includes principles and design guidance to construct streets on which transit can succeed through schedule reliability and safety.I’m really excited about the guide’s contents, which can can be used by transit agencies to outline capital street improvements critical to support successful transit operations. Here’s NACTO’s Matthew Roe giving a preview:Next, Remix is headed to the California Transit Association Conference in Pasadena, November 18–20. We’ll be back with more field updates! And for even more, follow me on Twitter at @tweetsupa.Cover image: David Grant

title: Erykah Badu And Rick Ross, “Window Seat” Remix And “Turn Me Away (Get Munny)”
content: Erykah Badu And Rick Ross, “Window Seat” Remix And “Turn Me Away (Get Munny)”Dave BryBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingAug 10, 2010Here’s the good-looking cliffhanger of a new video Erykah Badu made with Rick Ross, who everyone for some reason loves right now. I don’t much. “BMF” is great. Really great. But like Ross’s first big hit, “Hustlin’” from 2005, it’s mostly the beat. Made by rising Virginian producer Lex Lugar, it’s big and open in a way that suits the heavyset rapper’s blustery style. But most everything else I’ve heard leaves me pretty cold.While people, some of whose opinions I very much respect, gush over the “lush,” “magisterial” soundscapes of the “Maybach Music” “series, those backdrops never sound right for his raps. Badu sounds okay on that stuff, Barry White would sound better. Ross sounds just sounds off-pace and swallowed up to me, and-I really don’t know what it is that people are hearing-his lyrics are really never anything to write home about. He often doesn’t rhyme and he usually gives the impression that he thinks what he’s saying is extremely momentous-and it’s not. When he calls himself “Biggie Smalls in the flesh” on the oddly interesting, but still mostly clumsy “Tears of Joy,” you wish Lloyd Bentsen was standing at a podium next to him.

title: Video: 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method)
content: Video: 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method)Scott MyersBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 14, 2016I have been tracking Kirby Ferguson and his “Everything is a Remix” videos since the very first one came out in 2010. So when Kirby reached out to me via email about his latest video — “The 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method #1) — I had to check it out. Here it is:Kirby contends ideas derive from the subconscious mind. However everything we experience in the conscious realms feeds the subconscious. As Kirby puts it, “The subconscious mind cooks the meal, but the conscious mind buys all the groceries.”In the video, Kirby talks about four steps:1. Create boundaries.2. Consume everything you can within these boundaries.3. Digest the research.With these three steps, as Kirby puts it, “You’ve thrown a bunch of ingredients into a pot. By processing these material as much as you’re capable, you’ve started your subconscious mind on generating an idea.” What to do next?4. Drop it. Kirby: “Take a vacation. Go out with family and friends. Take a walk. Clean the house. Do some gardening. After a while, your subconscious mind will complete its work and an idea will pop up.”I can get behind this as one approach to generating ideas. From my own experience, I know how ideas can emerge when I am as far away from thinking about them as possible. For example, when I’m out for a run and my mind hits a kind of blank zone, suddenly — BING! An idea. Or taking a shower. Staring out the window. Moments when the conscious mind is preoccupied. I’m sure you’ve had surprising insights like this, too.That said, I also believe that for some writers, myself included, intentional and conscious efforts to brainstorm ideas — using the magic words ‘what if,’ playing around with existing story concepts and genre-, gender-, and geo-bending them, and so on — can result in ‘new’ story ideas. As Kirby says in his previous video serious, “Everything is a remix.” Why not embrace that and consciously attempt to generate story ideas?That said, Kirby’s latest video is a great take on not only respecting the role of our subconscious mind in the creative process, but also feeding it with stimuli in the expectation it will eventually surprise us with an idea.Here is the combo plate of Kirby’s first four videos in the Everything is a Remix series:For the rest of Kirby’s videos, go here.Where do your ideas come from? Conscious mind? Subconscious mind? Magic? Let me know your thoughts in comments.

title: Ubuntu Netbook Remix
content: Ubuntu Netbook RemixTom CheesewrightBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 17, 2009This morning I finally got around to testing out the Ubuntu Netbook Remix on my little Acer AspireOne. I’m writing this blog post on it now, and though I’ve had limited time for testing, so far I am really impressed.For one thing, the Vodafone Mobile Broadband dongle just works: plug and play. That is a big plus point.The whole interface is a massive improvement over the default too. A lot of thought has gone into creating a lightweight but attractive platform for small, low-power devices. Well done Canonical and all involved in the development effort.If you want to try it out, you just need to download the IMG file from here and write it to a 1GB flash drive. I found that to be simpler on a Windows machine using Win32 Image Writer, though I’d appreciate anyone offering a guide to doing it in Linpus — the default Acer operating system.Before you do anything else, I’d recommend backing your whole system up. Macles has kindly made that very straightforward: find instructions and software downloads on his/her blog.Only downside I’ve found is that the WiFi switch no longer works. I can cope with that though.

title: Lyeform — Stigma / TMSV remix
content: Lyeform — Stigma / TMSV remixWil BentonBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 6, 2016With grime rolling through to reach the peak of its popularity cycle once more, the natural movement of the sound (and its wider influences) has enabled a number of new talents to flourish — producers, DJs and record labels. One such label is the newly established imprint Mo:zaïek Music.The Belgium-based label is debuting its vinyl first releases timed for a summer drop — and they’re not hanging about with MZK001. It’s a weighty plate that features London’s Lyeform, backed by Dutch badman, FKOF fam and allround nice guy TMSV on the remix.Ahead of its release in early June, we had the opportunity to check the Stigma EP (including TMSV’s ‘Rusty 3 Star’ remix) and put pen to paper…The FKOF Review“Lyeform has appeared on our radar a few times recently, with frequent Rinse FM airplay thanks to the Keysound Recordings gang. TMSV, while managing to focus on his legal studies, has continued to set the bar with his up-tempo endeavours as of late. With support from the likes of Om Unit, Danny Scrilla and J:Kenzo, Utrecht’s finest has collaborated with the London-based producer to deliver some hot, hot heat.“Lyeform’s Stigma’ is one of those tunes designed for dark, smokey dancefloors in abandoned warehouses. The producer has implemented some bitter samples and thugged-out atmospheres to create a dubstep-infused grime vibe that will drive listeners to and then over the edge. The way his raw kicks, a tough snare and dirty stabs correspond with the bass inside the mix is astounding. He has stepped out of his comfort zone to deliver a true sound system rumbler.”“TMSV’s contribution to Mo:zaïek’s debut release kicks the hornet’s nest and then sets fire to it. It’s a fierce rework that contains some truly barbaric basslines, a low-pressure zone and corrosive leads that bring total destruction to the dance. It builds to a sonic boom that results in uncontrollable head-nodding, skanking and an old-school fever. The TSMV remix sticks in the mind, making it an essential contribution to Mo:zaïek’s debut release.”MZK001 drops 06/06/2016 Pre-order it from White Peach here.Peace, love and respect.FKOF

title: Lady Gaga — The Remix: misma propuesta para diferente público
content: Lady Gaga — The Remix: misma propuesta para diferente públicoHipersónicaBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 19, 2010Lady Gaga, independientemente de gustos y preferencias, es una de las artistas que mejor han sabido montarse una imagen y una marca en torno a sí al estilo de lo que hizo Madonna en su día, salvando las distancias. Su debut, The Fame, ha ido dejando que sus temas goteen poco a poco, sin prisa, generando tal afluencia de seguidores — y detractores — como hacía tiempo que no se veía.Después llegó The Fame Monster y vimos cómo se puede lanzar un EP compuesto inicialmente de canciones que iban a aparecer en una edición especial de The Fame y romper de nuevo los mercados, pariendo un segundo trabajo digno y que no desmerece al debut. Con ambos afianzó su público y los que no la soportaban seguían sin hacerlo, pero el nuevo lanzamiento de Lady Gaga puede llegar a un sector en el que quizá antes resultó descafeinada.The Remix es el original título con el que se ha bautizado esta recopilación de remezclas en el que participan gente como Stuart Price, Pet Shop Boys o Passion Pit, lo que a priori hace que pique la curiosidad por ver qué vuelta le han dado a un grupo de canciones que de por sí podrían llegar a las pistas de baile sin aditivos ni conservantes.Sin embargo, la línea general de este álbum es mucho más electrónica y menos edulcorada en este sentido que la de sus fuentes, los dos primeros discos de la Germanotta. Si hay algo que sí se ha conservado, al menos para mi gusto, es que las canciones que más gustaban en su versión original siguen triunfando reinterpretadas por estos DJs. Una de las que más y mejor destacan es la vuelta que le ha dado Stuart Price a la fantástica y ácida ‘Paparazzi‘, dándole un toque casi melancólico y para la que Lady Gaga grabó de nuevo la parte vocal. Me gusta incluso más que la original.http://www.youtube.com/v/zquoRDyINeM&hl=es_ES&fs=1&Pet Shop Boys se ha encargado de remezclar ‘Eh Eh (Nothing Else Can I Say)‘ y basta con escuchar la apertura del tema y esa afición al sintetizador que tienen para reconocerlos instantáneamente. Eso sí, su apuesta me gusta más que la que ha hecho Frankmusik sobre esta misma canción, comparad:Pet Shop Boys:http://www.youtube.com/v/9YbLv5W4-X8&hl=es_ES&fs=1&http://www.youtube.com/v/Z07TpZcde14&hl=es_ES&fs=1&Alphabeat:http://www.youtube.com/v/hx8M7HDd3e4&hl=es_ES&fs=1&http://www.youtube.com/v/32b7Ik61sY0&hl=es_ES&fs=1&http://www.youtube.com/v/unXr-zDPhTo&hl=es_ES&fs=1&Soy poco amiga de recopilatorios, como ya sabréis a estas alturas, y generalmente los discos de remezclas me dejan bastante indiferente. Sigo prefiriendo los trabajos originales de Lady Gaga con mucho. Aun así, en el caso de este The Remix, sin llegar a ser ser imprescindible, le he de reconocer que varios de sus temas han sido enriquecidos y que en general la apuesta abrirá aún más las puertas del éxito entre un sector más amigo del sonido electrónico y del dance que del pop que fue su carta de presentación.

title: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation Authority
content: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation AuthorityRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 7, 2016When the Puerto Rico Integrated Transportation Authority — known locally as ATI — was created by Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla in summer 2014, the island’s transportation paradigm was altered considerably in in terms of both new, different routes and service operations.EFGB Consulting Engineers was contracted by ATI to manage the design, planning, and adoption of the new routes. Its goal was to “reduce impact to the community to the minimum possible” during the agency shakeup, which brought down the number of lines from 37 to 27 overseen by ATI, says engineer Francisco Klein. Francisco and his team used Remix to assess the conditions of existing service prior to ATI’s conception, consider demographic and costing information for the new routes, and compare the two. In addition, the information provided by Remix was used in PRITA’s Title VI compliance report, justifying the changes from the 2013 routes to 2015 routes.Jane, our isochrone, was particularly useful for Francisco’s work. “We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked,” he says, “What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?”Viewing Census data in Remix’s layers also helped his team see the social impact — particularly on senior, youth, and car-free populations — of the route changes. In Puerto Rico, taking transit is too often stigmatized as an indicator that you don’t have the ability to own a car, Francisco says. As a result, EFGB has focused on creating “an efficient and reliable system so that people who need it most use it and can say, ‘Yeah, this is working very well, and it’s meeting the goal and expectations,’ and that could eventually translate into more people seeing transit as an alternative.”While ATI is regulating and controlling the new routes planned for the Metropolitan Area of San Juan, the consultants have used Remix to consider systems in other municipalities of the island. Those local services will ultimately work with the systems and routes ATI proposes at an island-wide level. To foster strong and effective service between ATI and the municipal routes, Francisco focused on population data. “We didn’t want to have a system that would be spending too much money and having very limited ridership, so we made sure that we could reach areas with population concentration” in Aguadilla, on Puerto Rico’s north coast, and several municipalities on the southeastern side.“I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually,” says Francisco. “You’d have to basically lay out the routes, and then go looking for the different layers in different systems. So having everything integrated right there, it’s just cost-effective, it’s efficient overall.”While data on ATI’s revamped bus system has yet to be calculated — the new lines were only implemented this past summer — Francisco says that his team “recognize[d] that some of the routes were just too long, and so Remix has been very helpful in assessing that the proposed routes are not as long as they used to be. That way, we think we’re taking one step in the right direction of having a more efficient and reliable system.”Moving forward, EFGB will do ride-check and point-check studies to determine the impact of the new routes. Once the data analysis process has been completed, they plan to continue to use Remix to assess potential route changes based on the collected data.Photo via Flickrcase-study prita puerto-rico

title: New iPod Shuffle Needs A Remix
content: New iPod Shuffle Needs A RemixNYU LocalBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 27, 2009By Zane BrzezinskiGreat debaters the download.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/shuffle.png” alt=”shuffle” width=”249" height=”280" />[Ed. note: This post was submitted by Zane Brzezinski, our new tech writer in the National section.]On the morning of March 11, Apple unleashed its newest iPod into the wild, a fresh update on the Shuffle. The first thing you’ll notice is that it’s small as hell. Smaller than a double-A battery in fact. But size doesn’t matter (at least that’s what my last girlfriend said), it’s how the thing works. So does the $79 mp3 player deserve to enter the hallowed hall of iPods, or will it fall flat on its face?The first thing you’ll notice about the new Shuffle is that there is only one way to interact with the device itself. On top is a small off/on/shuffle switch. Everything else is controlled by a small remote that sits on the new headphones, much like the earbuds that ship with the iPhone. Although this allows for the sleek-as-hell buttonless design, there are a few obvious problems that come along in tow.If you’re anything like me, you have a discarded pair of white earbuds lying around somewhere in your room. That’s because Apple’s headphones suck. They don’t sound good, they aren’t durable, and they sure as hell aren’t comfortable. The problem with the new Shuffle is that once you tire of the shoddy bass/bleeding inner ears/broken buds (and believe you me, they will break), you have absolutely no way of controlling the Shuffle. Sure, if you plug in another pair of headphones and switch the thing on, music starts to play. But what if you want to go to another song? Too bad. Want to pause? Not happening. Want to turn up the volume? You’re out of luck.And just in case you can deal with headphones, don’t think you’ll be able to navigate as easily as your traditional iPod. Apple has a chart on their website on how to properly utilize the new earbud remote that’s more confusing than the NYUHome dinosaur. For example, if you want to go to the previous track and you’ve listened to more than six seconds of the current track, it’s no easy matter. You have to click the remote SIX TIMES to go back one song. Sure, that tap-tap-tap-tap-tap-tap might not sound too bad, but you know how you can do that easier? One tap with any other mp3 device ever made. You know…one with controls?The only real benefit to the device is the Stephen Hawking sound-a-like that tells you what track you are listening to. Except he wouldn’t be necessary if Apple had just gone ahead and put a screen on the thing. It seems to have worked well for every other useful gadget ever.So is the new shuffle worth it? Absolutely not. If you’re in the market for a small iPod, just shell out the extra $70 for a Nano. You’ll get great bonus features like: a screen, controls, and retaining your sanity.Photo courtesy of Flickr user designmilk.

title: What does a line on a map mean? How Southwest Idaho understood the benefits of BRT.
content: What does a line on a map mean? How Southwest Idaho understood the benefits of BRT.RemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJun 25, 2018Boise, ID, one of America’s fastest growing cities: flickr user: John PennyFor most people, it’s hard to know what a line on a map signifies. How fast will the bus go? Will it get me to my destination on time? And for decision makers, it’s hard to know if the extra investment is worth it.For Duane Wakan, formally of the Community Planning Association (COMPASS), being able to visualize choices — and costs — turned out to be the best way to win support for an ambitious transportation network for Southwest Idaho.Not Enough ServiceTreasure Valley — home to about 688,000 people in Ada and Canyon counties — is projected to grow by 2040 to just over a million residents. The agency is planning for the future and searching for a dedicated, sustainable funding source. It is updating its long range plan, Communities in Motion 2040 2.0, and Duane is developing more robust and necessary transportation services.“Before I got here, there was a consultant hired to help develop a vision for public transportation for the Treasure Valley. It was building upon the existing system, and they constrained the growth of the transit system based on block density population and employment densities,” Duane said. “It didn’t provide a lot of access for the Treasure Valley.”Today’s transit in the Treasure ValleyMuch of the existing design is inefficient, with circuitous routing. Meridian, the second largest city in Idaho, has little transit services, and Caldwell and Nampa have a combined population of 160,000 residents yet only have access to six routes. “Currently there are no high frequent routes 15 minute headways or better in the Treasure Valley,” Duane said. “Compare that to Wenatchee, Washington, population 115,000 has 19 routes with three high frequent routes.“Public outreach during the first Communities in Motion effort source: The Blue ReviewThrough board meetings and discussions with elected officials, consensus grew for a more comprehensive vision. Leaders asked for bus rapid transit, too, which meant Duane would have to start fresh. “Successful projects are not just putting a line on a map and saying oh, we’ve got this transit system already, let’s throw in a high capacity transit line and call that something that would serve the region,” he said. “The intent is to fully integrate and redesign around high capacity transit.”Real-time Remix VisualizationJane — Remix’s feature that maps a transit shed instantaneously — was key. Placing Jane anywhere in a city helps not only see how far a rider can go on any given route but also the effect of bus speed.Using Remix, Duane chose Boise as the point of origin and then isolated the proposed BRT route. In real-time he showed the transportation working group members what would happen if the buses’ average speed more than doubled. “I said, let’s show what our existing average speed is for the bus, which is 12 and half miles per hour, and how far can Jane go in 15, 30, 45, 60 minute transit sheds,” Duane recalled. “And then, as I increased the speed, I pushed it up to an average 30 mph, and then I could show, ‘This is why we need to make investments in this corridor. Investments matter.’”Duane’s image showing the impact of BRT (at a travel speed of 12.5 miles per hour)Comparing the current and potential future transit influence in the Treasure Valley.The dramatic expansion of access, shown as isochrones, convinced the group. To add in a high capacity route, Duane moved from loops to a trunk-and-feeder design. “Remix was really critical for us to analyze frequencies, showing how we can make improvements to our system to make it more attractive for future growth,” he said.Duane found the software intuitive. “As I developed each of these iterations, I could identify the operations costs. I could talk about the improvements and frequency as we moved throughout time from our existing system to 2040,” he said. “Remix was really cool. With the new vehicle types, I was able to talk about commuter rail, and I was able to find the per hour costs.”Cost-Benefit AnalysisIn developing the different transit systems, Duane used Remix to output the operations costs. “I showed that with the same amount of money, we could have a much more expansive system.”“Using Remix was really invaluable to me,” Duane said. “To be able to produce a long range plan, put in our unfunded list — ‘Hey, we’ve got this ambitious network, here’s what it’s gonna cost. Here’s the per capita contributions that we’ll need to make this happen.’ So it’s really been helpful.”The final plan goes forward for approval in December of 2018. Duane is pleased with the more expansive transportation network he’s developed for the Treasure Valley, and for the support it has received. Making real those one-dimensional lines made a big difference. “When you try to communicate to audiences goals, objectives, and strategies, it’s really difficult to show them, ‘what is improved access? What does that look like?’” he said. “We can use Remix to paint that picture visually. We can communicate to our elected officials and our planners why these are important objectives and strategies.”Duane says Remix helped him tell the story, to make the system understandable. He added, “I am more visual. If I can’t visualize things, how can I explain it to the public? That’s how I see the world.”

title: Pop-Up Remix during #HipHopEd
content: Pop-Up Remix during #HipHopEdGreg McVerryBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 7, 2016In a recent post on my backstage blog (I use it to describe process or half baked thoughts) I explained my excitement for #HipHopEd in order to gather some song lyrics. I am pop culture deficient yet carry some knowledge of early hip hop. I got there on a strange path long after the original tracks dropped..but that is another story.Storify [Slideshow]Edit descriptionstorify.comI was excited for the chat just to archive cool crowdsourced lyrics. I would have the chance to grow a collection from people who recognize the literacy practices of all youth while recognizing that education is central to social movements.Gear UpOur Gear Up students, are entering the eleventh grade — a crucial year for the college bound. This year I want to transition our text message outreach from parents (who will receive reminders and event updates) to students. We Use Remind. I will set up new classes for youth. I am thinking a motivational quote throwdown will be a fun activity.Meme MakingQuotes make great memes and memes make great tools for learning basic HTML and CSS. In fact I shared a template I had remixed from Mozilla Learning. I hope to use these during #EDU106. o I decided to make on the fly. As I saw quotes I made a series of remixes for participants in the chat.In each remix I used a creative commons image from Flickr. Using Alan Levine’s Flickr CC Attribution helper I was able to use a legally licensed image while providing some amazing artists credit. In the train picture I actually remixed two images. It isn’t much of a composition. I was constrained by time as I was trying to make a few memes while also participating in the chat.All I used was the eraser and the opacity tools…Still looks pretty cool. I may keep working on it.I hope others in the #HipHopEd community takes up the call to #teachtheweb. Hip Hop has a long history of digital arts. We need to grow this legacy while getting mroe students of color to code. Do I believe every kid should code. No, but everyone should have the opportunity to explore their identities across the web while mastering skills that can open up opportunities that have been closed off for the first three decades of our online world.

title: Kanye West With Justin Bieber and Raekwon, “Runaway Love (Remix);” Kanye West With Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver, “Monster”
content: Kanye West With Justin Bieber and Raekwon, “Runaway Love (Remix);” Kanye West With Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver, “Monster”Dave BryBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingAug 31, 2010The busy, busy Kanye West took a pretty simple approach to his much-hyped bringing together of teeny-bopper Justin Bieber and the Wu-Tang Clan’s Raekwon: he basically recorded Rae and himself rapping over the grimy finger-snap beat from the 1993’s “Wu-Tang Clan Ain’t Nuthing Ta F’ Wit” (funny that, when Rae was so careful to write lyrics appropriate for his 16-year-old co-star), and laid clips of Bieber’s vocal track overtop for the chorus. But in the way that shows how simple is so often best, it sounds pretty great. It definitely has the feel of the mid-’90s heyday of hip-hop/R&B; mashups. You could almost imagine hearing it between Method Man and Mary J. Blige’s “All I Need” and Mariah’s “Fantasy” remix with O.D.B. at the Tunnel. And at least from the first few listens, I prefer it to this other Kanye track that came out over the weekend, “Monster,” featuring Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver.

title: Kim Cameron and Wideboys Release Hottest New Remix
content: Kim Cameron and Wideboys Release Hottest New RemixMoon on the Water is more than just a deep house mixMike LemaicBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingSep 17, 2016September 25, 2016, London, United Kingdom — -This week, 2-Time Billboard Top 20 artist, Kim Cameron, releases her newest single in collaboration with the UK’s famous chart topping duo; the Wideboys. Moon on the Water is the 25th single from her new album ‘Naturally Yours’ which has already earned top 150 placement on the National DRT Radio Chart, five #1 slots on several DJ dance charts in the U.S., and top 20 on Mediabase Pop charts.Moon on the Water has just begun releasing to the UK’s Pop Chart indicator stations and is a mixture of pure creamy pop vocals with deep house beats. The music video was shot in Cameron’s hometown of Miami Beach during the summer’s peak full moon season.The release hits the virtual streets in the UK first, in conjunction with Cameron’s promotional tour to London, the week of October 3rd. Her tour includes ‘Late Night with Monica Price,’ ‘Deeside Radio,’ several on-air radio stations and other media outlets, to name a few, before attending a private event in the heart of London.“As soon as we heard Kim’s voice we were inspired to try and create something magical that conjured up the feeling of watching the reflection of the moon in the sea at midnight whilst dancing with hundreds of happy people!” said Eddie from the Wideboys.This year has marked not only an amazing accolades year for Cameron with her album success between the charts and signing several major licensing contracts with Korean, Chinese and French agencies, but also a technological one. Cameron released a ‘Kim Cameron and Side FX CalendarCalendar Appapp last month — free for fans — to stay engaged with her and band. In addition, along with her release of Moon on the Water, she is releasing her full album on SD Micro cards (with adapters who still use a computer) for quick cell phone listening.“I am definitely not an old school thinker. I teach music to kids part-time, so I am always trying to figure out where they are going next. Focusing around technology that uses your phone is just where they are,” explained Cameron.Side FX and Kim Cameron are a high-energy, 2-time Top 20 Billboard chart-topping dance band who’s music has been on Billboard Dance Club, Hot AC, AC; College Music Journal; AAA, DJ Times, FMQB music charts.Kim is played across the US, Canada, UK and Australia, and placed on Bravo, Fox Sports, MTV, Discovery, TLC, TV Networks, just to name a few.Kim Cameron, who performed twice for the NFL (Giants and Redskins) to over 70,000, has toured across the country and internationally, garnered millions of YouTube views, featured on Comcast’s Xfinity, and won Album of the Year, Best Live Performance, American Songwriter Nominee and a Silver Medal from Global Music Awards.For more on Kim Cameron, visit http://www.sidefxmusic.com.

title: Raekwon Records Verse That Fits The Criteria For Kanye West’s Remix Of Justin Bieber Song
content: Raekwon Records Verse That Fits The Criteria For Kanye West’s Remix Of Justin Bieber SongDave BryBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingAug 20, 2010Kanye West has organized an unexpected musical collaboration, recruiting Wu-Tang Clan’s Raekwon the Chef to rhyme on a remix of Justin Bieber’s “Runaway Love.” Bieber is 16 years old, the age at which Raekwon started smoking the crack-laced marijuana cigarettes called “woolies.” But Rae told MTV’s Shaheem Reid that the verse he recorded for the track is age-appropriate for Bieber’s presumably less experienced tween audience. “I can go basic when I want to. I can go rated R, I can go rated PG. I definitely didn’t give him anything that I thought was too hot to be spoken on by a 16-year-old… One thing people gotta recognize about me, I’m the Chef. I know how to make spicy food, I know how to make food that ain’t spicy. I made something that fit the criteria.” Certainly, that’s good. But if the world had a better sense of humor, Bieber would be sitting in a bathtub of milk for the video, sucking his thumb.In other Kanye remix news, a new version of the great “Power” single has just come out. It features an introductory verse from Jay-Z and an unfortunate reinterpolation of the original chorus, replacing the wonderful vocal snippet from King Crimson’s “21st Century Schizoid Man,” with a clunky, much less wonderful recording of the phrase, “No one man should have all that power…” But then it breaks, and switches to a new beat that samples Snap’s “I Got The Power,” and Kanye’s new verses are passionate and exciting. He’s doing really good right now.

title: Depeche Mode están que lo tiran: regalo de un remix para promocionar su nueva colección de remixes
content: Depeche Mode están que lo tiran: regalo de un remix para promocionar su nueva colección de remixesHipersónicaBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJun 1, 2011Ya os hemos puesto al sobre aviso en más de una ocasión: Depeche Mode tienen una segunda parte para su disco de remezclas, bajo el título de Remixes 2: 81–11. Pues bien, lo tenemos encima ya, como quien dice, ya que este triple recopilatorio estará en la calle el 7 de junio, y eso, como podéis imaginar, conlleva promoción.Si ya se ha publicado el EP para ‘Personal Jesus‘ con sus correspondientes remezclas y se han colgado muchas de ellas para su escucha en streaming, como ya os avisó Victor Rodríguez en su momento, ahora llega la hora de los regalos.Porque no hay mejor forma de llamar la atención del público que ofreciendo contenido gratis (y legalmente) y un disco como este, conlleva una gran convocatoria de artistas electrónicos para que realicen sus remezclas sobre los originales, y como es natural, todas no caben en el plástico de un cd, así que hay que dejar algunas fuera.Pero, al igual que del cerdo se aprovecha todo, el trabajo de un artista no se debe nunca tirar a la papelera (de reciclaje) y si no hay hueco en el disco, se le busca como regalo.http://player.soundcloud.com/player.swf?url=http%3A%2F%2Fapi.soundcloud.com%2Ftracks%2F15633506Dicho y hecho: desde el mismo Facebook de la banda, nos redirigen a Fact Magazine para hacernos con ‘Master And Servant (RSS Remix)‘ por la patilla. Si, es cierto, como podréis escuchar, no satisfará en exceso a los seguidores de Depeche Mode de toda la vida, pero al fin y al cabo, los más fanáticos, coleccionistas avariciosos que no pueden dejar escapar un sólo tema de Gahan y los suyos pueden frotarse las manos incorporando una nueva referencia a sus bibliotecas musicales. Por lo demás, si no sois djs ni aficionados a la música de baile, podéis dejarlo correr, que no os perdéis nada imprescindible, aunque para muestra, el botón de ahí arriba.Vía | Depeche Mode en FacebookDescarga | Master And Servant (RSS Remix)En Hipersónica | Martin Gore y Vince Clarke terminan su álbum y Depeche Mode editarán un disco de remezclas en abril

title: BT — These Re-Imagined Machines, el remix treatment para el These Hopeful Machines
content: BT — These Re-Imagined Machines, el remix treatment para el These Hopeful MachinesHipersónicaBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMay 18, 2011Hace ya más de un año que dimos un repaso a These Hopeful Machines, el último álbum hasta la fecha de Brian Transeau, más conocido por todos bajo su nombre artístico, BT. Por entonces ya nos deshicimos en elogios hacia uno de los artistas más completos de la electrónica, ya que es capaz, tanto de componer y programar su propia música, cantar muchos de sus propios temas, como de crear software para este fin, haciendo gala de sus extensos conocimientos musicales.Recientemente, el mes pasado concretamente, recibíamos These Humble Machines, una edición de aquel álbum que, sinceramente, no merece mucho la pena. Yo no encuentro apenas diferencias con el original, y la única justificación de compra sería que se nos hubiera escapado la primera versión del álbum en su día.Próximamente, el 31 de mayo, se publicará una recopilación que si que merece la pena, sobre todo si sois de los que gustan más de remixes que de originales. Porque, como mandan los cánones actuales, se trata de un álbum que recoge en dos discos las mejores remezclas realizadas sobre los temas del disco original, incluyendo también remixes especialmente creados para este lanzamiento, que saldrá de nuevo a través de Black Hole y con el título de These Re-Imagined Machines.http://www.youtube.com/v/R2JsvjSKE6AEn total serán 17 los remixes que se incluyan en esta doble recopilación, y entre ellos figuran nombres como los de Adam K & Soha, Funkagenda, Ferry Corsten, Mr. Sam, Armin van Buuren o Chicane, por citar algunos. title: The Swarovski Remix Collection Takes Personal Style To Another Level-Women Holiday Gift Guide
content: The Swarovski Remix Collection Takes Personal Style To Another Level-Women Holiday Gift GuideDeniseBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 28, 2018I was super excited to be invited to this event, and get a chance to review the new Fall 2018 Remix Collection. This is also a collection that will make the perfect gift for the holidays. The Swarovski Remix Collection will make any jewelry lover feel like a kid in a candy store.As much as we love smart tech accessories and devices there’s just something about classic accessories with a modern twist that makes for pretty great workday companions. And so, to help you take your working woman power-dressing to the next level, Swarovski released the Swarovski Remix Collection beautiful jewelry designs featuring an innovative magnetic feature that allows you to customize and create an endless combination of bracelets and necklaces. Think of it like this — you can have a gorgeous new piece of jewelry to match your every outfit, occasion, or even your mood!The newest additions to this (re)mix are the easy-to-clip-on Swarovski Remix Collection Charms featuring Swarovski crystal pavé letters, colorful birthstones, and shimmering symbols. The magnetic feature is, once again, the key element here. But the designs are stunning as well! Swarovski Remix Collection. Feminine, elegant and unique, the collection is full of pieces that will effortlessly put the finishing touch on your outfit. And thanks to a magnetic closure that lets you create bracelets and necklaces of various lengths to suit your mood and occasion, it’s the perfect fix for the modern woman who wants to go from desk to holiday event.Turn two bracelets into a party choker, or link several up for an elegant piece for a dinner affair. It’s all about expressing your individual style and having maximum versatility while complementing the look you want. Then, there are the crystal pavé rose gold letters that allow you to add an even more personal touch; and delicate birthstone and lucky charms like the evil eye or hamsa hand that are as perfect for your best friend as they are for yourself.As Swarovski’s Creative Director Nathalie Colin says of the new collection: “Jewellery is an expression of our individual personality, our style, and taste. It is very personal and can, therefore, give a strong identity to every single look. At Swarovski we believe in empowering women to express themselves through our jewellery, to shine brightly and let their sparkle light up the world all day.”The charms start at $39, and the Charm Starter Set (which includes a charm and a sparkling Remix carrier strand) is $99. The collection will be available in-store and online from today. If you want to make someone happy this holiday season, this is the perfect gift.

title: Giovani Ribulli REMIX
content: Giovani Ribulli REMIXMatteo BordoneBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingNov 23, 2006Si potrebbero anche ipotizzare delle leggi, dei postulati, dei teoremi relativi a come le notizie fatte di fuffa, di paglia, di niente montato a neve, riescano a riprodursi (come le palle di lanugine a scuola in un pezzo di Wilcock). Insomma, proliferano e nessuno ne sente il bisogno. Ma così funziona in Italia. Non si raccontano le storie di cronaca, sui giornali, ma si fa la cronaca a partire dalle storie. Si stabilisce un tema del momento e, anche non riuscendo a trovare notizie che ci abbiano a che fare, se ne prendono altre e le si accorpa. Insomma in un modo o nell’altro ‘sta pagina la dobbiamo chiudere. Dobbiamo chiudere e chiuderemo.Ovvio che la distanza dalla realtà sia direttamente proporzionale all’ignoranza e al disinteresse del tema stesso da parte dei giornalisti. I giovani sono un tema tipico. I giovani non esistono come argomento, per come la pensano i nostri giornalisti, perché non sono esattamente persone. I giovani sono i cuccioli dei vecchi. Cresceranno. Inutile stare a capirli che tanto tra cinque anni sono tutti cambiati. È lavoro sprecato. Se ne parla, ma in un altro senso. I giovani sono un tema sociale. Ecco. Sono il probblema dei ggiovani. Loro e quello che li circonda.Ora, è partito questo ricettone diabolico fatto, al livello più alto, di giovani, violenza e tecnologia (due temi di cui i giornalisti dei quotidiani in genere non sanno una mazza, con un bigné in mezzo). Cioè, c’è chi ne sa, di quello che ascoltano leggono e fanno i giovani, ma non parla con chi fa il pezzo di cronaca sul bigné violento alla crema di aiuto. Nello specifico i giovani sono bulli, violenti, coi pixel in faccia che non li si riconosce neanche. E la tecnologia è fatta di videogiochi violenti, cellulari che riprendono cattiverie e violenze, siti internet che pubblicano video, indovinate un po’, immorali e violenti. È un inferno, ‘sto tecnologia. Quasi peggio dei giovani.Capite che siamo davanti a un mostro che potrebbe vivere di vita propria e masticare pagine di cellulosa per mesi, prima di tornare in letargo.È normale tutto questo? Io mi ostino a credere di no. Che non sia normale e che negli altri paesi sia diverso. Che le foto della Ventura col suo nuovo fidanzato siano in homepage di Repubblica e non più solo su Eva Tremila, qualcosa vorrà dire. Forse considerano la rete un circo equestre. Forse hanno troppi canali di distribuzione di contenuti e pochi contenuti. Forse hanno perso la direzione e vanno a vista. Boh, una di queste di sicuro. Perché in tutto il panorama dei quotidiani italiani solo Jaime D’Alessandro scrive cose sensate a proposito di videogiochi? Ho l’impressione che a differenza di quello che succedeva qualche tempo fa, quando la nicchia si lamentava ma in effetti per la gran parte della società Luzzatto Fegiz era più che sufficiente come tasso di contemporaneità e internazionalità musicale, ora le cose stiano cambiando. E come sempre si vede dagli angoli, dai dettagli. Non da come parlano di finanziaria, ma da come parlano del videogioco Rule of Rose, da come raccontano un rave, un singolo, un sito, il sesso, le canne e i manga. Lo scollamento adesso si vede di più. Naturalmente, come un cane si gratta quando ha il prurito, i lettori e i giornali cambieranno senza pensarci. L’aspetto divertente della vicenda sta nel come e nel quando.

Nichole leads our team.Education: BS Civil and Environmental Engineering from University of California, Davis; MBA from Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania.Previous Experience: Head of Customer Success at Fond (formerly AnyPerk), C3 IoT (formerly C3 Energy), Director of Contact Center Operations at Pacific Gas & Electric Company; Leadership Development Principal, web developerFavorite Transit System: RATP in Paris because they make it easy to explore the city with very limited funds and even more limited French.Fun Fact: I went to seven different elementary schools, two middle schools, and two high schools. title: Cocoon celebra su 11 aniversario con Eleven Years Cocoon Recordings — Selected Remix Works

“Everything is a Remix” — Part 2 (Movies)Scott MyersBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingFeb 3, 2011So last August, I posted this:This is absolutely worth watching, not only for music lovers, but also per Hollywood’s long history of recycling plots and its current obsession with remakes, sequels, and taking pre-branded brands (e.g., Battleship, Sherlock Holmes) and making ‘new’ entertainment.Everything has been done before. Generating ‘fresh’ story concepts to write is a matter of the right mix of the right preexisting elements at the right time.“Everything is a Remix” by Kirby is going to be a 4-part series. You can go here to learn more. While you’re there, contribute a few coins to support this very cool series.Kirby is back with Part 2 which focuses on movies:A factoid from the video: From last 10 years, of the top 100 movies, 74 were sequels, remakes, and adaptations. Now you know why Hollywood does so many pre-branded brands: Because they make money.But more importantly is a point Kirby makes in the video: Creation requires influence. As storytellers, we build on the stories which have come before us.I definitely recommend you watch this latest installment of “Everything is a Remix.” It touches on some of the key aspects of what we teach at Screenwriting Master Class in the Core I: Structure and Concept class.Thanks to Atlanta for the link to Part 2.UPDATE: Thanks to The Bitter Script Reader for this link:I may be the only person in the universe who has yet to see this video, but having played music professionally for 7 years, it’s true: you can write just about any song you want with just four chords.

title: Takeaways: 2019 Texas Regional Workshop
content: Takeaways: 2019 Texas Regional WorkshopRemixBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingApr 8During the last week of March, the Remix Regional Workshop series took our team to Dallas, TX. We spent a full day with 18 planners from across the state. The daylong workshop served as a venue to connect face-to-face with colleagues, receive hands-on training, and offer a dedicated time to cross-pollinate.Morning Kickoff at DART HQWe believe one of the more valuable things we do is foster connections amongst our customers. We find that transit agencies often face similar challenges and when connected, find creative ways to overcome common planning problems. Here are a few takeaways and best practices shared throughout the day:Communicating data with ease — conversations involving data can be complexData is often difficult to communicate across multiple parties. Here are a few ideas that have proven to be successful in Texas:Establishing a strong public engagement strategy before kicking off a series of meetings is a great way to get stakeholder alignment earlier in the process. Set up a time to discuss the best methods for communicating data-driven decisions to your audience. Reflect on what has (or has not) worked out well in the past.Be intentional about how you communicate bus service. Consider using colors to represent different types of service: 1) Frequency: 0–20 mins = green, 21–40 = yellow, 41–60 mins orange or 2) Types of Service: local = blue, regional = green, limited/commuter = purpleLearning more about tradeoffs has a high value when making difficult decisions. Walking through a values exercise can help with getting an agreement by understanding tradeoffs (i.e. would you rather have a shorter distance to travel to a stop for more riders for slower service or have 97% of customers within an eight min walk of the higher frequency service).Cap Metro’ s Remap project exhibits great examples of communicating data with ease. Click here to learn more.Bus stops — is there a magic numberAgencies at the workshop presented a wide range of ideas when it came to the topic of bus stops. Some agencies are adding bus stops for the first time ever and others are considering stop consolidations. The main conclusions were:Different types of service and differing land use require different specifications for stop placement and need. Consider investing the time to understand spacing standards in your service area and don’t be afraid to revisit and redefine as needed.Engage with your riders and gather an understanding that represents a large group of riders. Have you ever thought about holding a public meeting on the bus? What a great way to physically meet riders where they are.Pro tip: Did you know the Remix Line Attributes export offers additional information about stop distance/spacing along a line?Mobility as a Service (MaaS) — how have Texas agencies embraced changeWe can all agree that a lot of innovation has been brought to the transportation/mobility space in the past 10 years. MaaS has been a buzzword at nearly every conference we’ve attended in the last year and DART is leading the way in Texas. Whether its implementing demand response zones or partnering with TNCs, the GoPass program is a great example of embracing the spirit of MaaS. Click here to learn more.CapMetro sharing learnings from CapRemapIf you’re a looking for expertise in any of the above areas let us know — we would love to connect you to a planner who is doing something in a similar capacity as you. Whether it’s taking big leaps to pave the future of MaaS or mastering the art and science of communicating with data, transit agencies in the state of Texas are hard at work.Let your Customer Success Manager know if you are interested in learning more about the Remix Regional Workshop series or where we might be stopping next.

title: JJ Lin teams up with Luis Fonsi for a Mandarin-Spanish remix of ‘Despacito’
content: JJ Lin teams up with Luis Fonsi for a Mandarin-Spanish remix of ‘Despacito’The world’s biggest song gets even biggerShanghaiist.comBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 31, 2018At long last, the most popular song of our time has a proper version in Mandarin.Singaporean pop star JJ Lin has teamed up with Puerto Rican singer Luis Fonsi for a Mandarin-Spanish version of the latter’s worldwide super-duper, ultra-hit “Despacito,” which is translated into Mandarin as 緩緩, meaning “slowly.”This new version of a song that you’ve likely already heard dozens if not hundreds of times, features the two artists showing off their language skills by singing a few words in their counterpart’s mother tongue during the choruses.“Despacito” was never properly released in mainland China and this version could help to bring the unquestionably catchy tune to a whole new audience, much like how Fonsi’s collaboration with Justin Bieber on an English-Spanish remix elevated his song to all new heights.Just released on Friday, the JJ-Lin & Luis Fonsi version has already tallied 2.6 million views on YouTube. Admittedly, it still has a bit of catching up to do before surpassing the original's 4.7 billion YouTube views.Check out the Mandarin remix below:Listen on QQ video.And the original:Btw, JJ Lin is kicking off his new world tour in Shanghai on March 17th.

title: Love — Adriano Roveri Remixes
content: Love — Adriano Roveri RemixesMaestro BillyBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingFeb 1, 2018Mais dois remixes na área.Agora quem criou foi o Adriano Roveri, DJ das antigas e mega produtor.Se quiser ouvir algumas das produções dele, tem AQUIBom, desta vez ele criou uma versão House e uma outra Chill para Love, uma das músicas do meu álbum Commute.Aqui estão as duas versões.Aqui está o que ele me contou sobre o processo de criação dos dois remixes:A versão “Chill” era para ser a House.Quando ouvi a versão original, e depois só o Acapella, me deu vontade de fazer algo House com timbres anos 90… o vocal me fez lembrar de umas coisas dessa época.Mesmo eu não usando muito loop pronto, comecei a testar alguns, para pelo menos ter um ponto de partida… e aí caiu num loop de bateria que eu gostei, mas que não tinha nada de House, e em cima dele me veio na cabeça todo o resto para fazer uma versão Lounge.A versão House eu já comecei pelos timbres do synth… um deles me lembrou alguns Houses de 94, 95, e usei um outro de fundo que me lembrou o Nomad — I wanna give you devotion.Usei uns snares no contratempo, que é bem a cara daquele Garage House do começo dos anos 90.Achei legal fazer nessa linha também, por conta de várias coisas que estão sendo lançadas hoje e que tem essa cara 90s, como a do MK — 17, que já era conhecido na época pelo Always.A referência do Nomad — I wanna give you devotion, caso você não se lembre é esta:E a música original que deu origem aos remixes é esta:Curtiu?Aqui no meu perfil do Spotify tem mais um monte de remixes e novas músicas.Tudo de bom,Billy.

title: Everything is a Remix
content: Everything is a RemixScott MyersBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingFeb 19, 2012I’ve been following this series of videos from Kirby Ferguson since his first of four entries. He just finished up the whole thing. Here are all four videos:Part 1: The Song Remains the SamePart 2: Remix Inc.Part 3: Elements of CreativityPart 4: System Failurehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yAmmtCJxJJYIf you don’t have time for all four and your focus is screenwriting, Parts 2 and 3 are must-sees. “Remix Inc.” explores the idea of ‘similar but different’ that pervades Hollywood’s thinking about movie and TV. Elements of Creativity is about.. well… creativity.It’s all been done before. And yet, it’s all somehow different. That is the dichotomy we, as writers, face when attempting to be creative. There’s magical formula how to do it right, but there is a premium put on immersing yourself in whatever medium and genre in which you hope to excel, both to know what’s been done before and how it’s been done.Comment Archive

title: Daily Exorcise — Part 1 (The HipHop Remix)
content: Daily Exorcise — Part 1 (The HipHop Remix)Sidin Sunny VadukutBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingOct 23, 2006Hey hey hey. Forgotten me already have you? Thought I was gone for good? You are very, very wrong but then I won’t blame you. Its not your fault really. How were you to know that I have been terribly busy with things of a rather personal nature. Of course I will share it with you, no secrets between reader and author on this blog, but not right now. The time is not right. Patience I tell you. All in good time.But what I CAN tell you is that I have joined a gym. A proper one with treadmills and exercycles and dumbbells and spindly things with weights and handles and steel and chrome and all. Yes I have joined a gym all over again.Sigh.Avid readers of this blog, yes all three of you, will know that Sidin Sunny Vadukut has always been most robust when it comes to matters of the waist. He has always enjoyed a good meal of tandoori chicken, rotis, dal makhani and custard followed by a soup and main course and has often been described, in friends circles, as ‘cuddly’, ‘well-fed’ and ‘cute in a healthy sort of way’. If anyone looked at me and quipped that the pounds were gathering around me in little jiggly ripples of cheer I would merely, and coolly, shrug them off the first time and then roundhouse kick them in the face the second. (Well not as much roundhouse kick as smother them between my elbows. I can’t actually lift my leg that high.)It was not a bad life really. With the right wardrobe of loose Fabindia kurtas and open-minded draw-string pants I was managing to maintain my self esteem nicely. (Yes there was that incident in that Air Deccan flight. But I ensure you I did not mean to get stuck like that and delay the onward sector by two hours.) Nothing to complain really. And yes pass me that Dal Makhani please. And a nan please. With BUTTER!But of late, because of this personal thing I was referring to earlier, I had to wear a lot more of those stodgy inflexible formal pants. So off I went and bought myself a few pairs of regulation navy blue and dark brown formal pants that no self-respecting man’s wardrobe is complete without. (Unless you are Bappi Lahiri perhaps. But I doubt even he respects himself. Awwa awwa it seems!)Then two weeks ago I suddenly noticed that something strange had happened to my pants. My feet went in alright and the shins and knees managed to enter without incident. Things began to get a little ‘testy’ higher up. By the time the fabric had been pulled up to my waist things were looking very very bad.When I mean ‘tight’ I don’t mean hold your breath in and slip in the button’ tight. Oh ho ho no. I mean ‘scream in agony, get at least one hernia and pass out’ tight. I immediately did what a man had to do. Especially if he wanted to stay one. I ripped off the worsted wool, settled into a lungi and let out a sigh of relief among other things.Except for one pair of jeans, which I could fit into by getting my roomies to hold the pair up open while I jumped feet first into the cavity from the dining table, the rest of my legwear lay crumpled around my bedroom laughing at me mockingly. Nothing irks like a deprecating length of corduroy.(Enter hip-hop type loop here. Rap following lines…)Things were getting out of hand.And my waistband.I was forced to understand.No more room to expand.No more the gourmand.Between long term health and death unplanned…this, mofo, was the final stand.(End loop. Wait for women to get off you and applause to die. Continue.)The very next day, after a pizza lunch, I ran to the gym next to my place here in Wadala. I stepped in with a heavy heart, a heavier wallet but with considerable determination.If you are one of those people who like economics a lot you will note, in addition to the fact that you have very few friends, how several economic theories are based on human beings being‘rational’. This means that they make logical decisions, are predictable and that he or she is a ratio or quotient of two integers, usually written as the vulgar fraction a/b, where b is not zero.Well then, step into any gym, go stand next to the billing area and you will see why the above reasoning is absofreakinglutely wrong. A gym membership is to disposable income what a blackhole is to light, a Vadukut is to spicy fish curry and a Bush is to crude producing nations without democracy. These memberships grab impressionable young men and women in their evil sweaty tentacles and suck them dry till the victim is left with no personal wealth except small change and Sodexho passes in awkward denominations. (When this happens you can only either have Idlis or Murgh Mussallam and nothing in between. It sucks.)Yet, in spite of the inevitable financial challenge, everyday thousands of young men weighing millions of kilos fork out hajjar for gym memberships. And they do this with rosy visions of high impact cardio programs, macho free weights routines, six-pack abs and, most importantly, for a decent shot at the hot dietician who comes in once a week.But for a person like me, with the aerodynamic quality of a teakwood sofa-cum-bed, the gym, alas, is the last resort. I just had to regain the perfect posture and endless stamina that had abandoned me, after years of neglect, sometime in kindergarten.So there I was. Melancholy yet intense. Sitting in a chair while I waited for the gym manager to initiate me into my gym routine. He was going to measure every measurable dimension of my body and then weigh me. After this I was supposed to get up, step over all the tiny pieces of my self-esteem that lay scattered across the floor, and go meet the dietician who would go over my readings and give me a review.Her eyes ran over the tiny ballpoint pen measurements while I looked at the weighing scale sitting ominously in a corner smirking.Is Sidin’s weight loss too big to solve? Will he ever be able to regain his self confidence and esteem? Will he ever be able to fit into his flat-fronted corduroys again? Will the dietician see the sensitive human being inside the cellulite? Is she single? Will Sidin ever write part two of a two-part blog?All that much more in Daily Exorcise — Part 2… Coming soon…

title: Un remix de ‘Born This Way’ de Lady Gaga, usado en un desfile de moda
content: Un remix de ‘Born This Way’ de Lady Gaga, usado en un desfile de modaHipersónicaBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 20, 2011Lady Gaga ya está preparando el terreno para el lanzamiento de Born This Way, su segundo disco de estudio, y tras el éxito arrollador que tuvo tanto con The Fame como con el EP que lo siguió, The Fame Monster, las apuestas no podrían estar más altas. Sumando las ventas de ambos trabajos, el resultado es la friolera de 15 millones de copias repartidas por todo el mundo. Está claro que más de uno está esperando esta nueva incursión.Born This Way tiene programada la fecha de lanzamiento para el 23 de mayo, aunque por suerte su primer single, titulado igual que el disco, aparecerá de manera oficial bastante antes, el 13 de febrero. Sin embargo, y debido a la relación de Lady Gaga y Nicola Formichetti, el nuevo diseñador creativo de Thierry Mugler, hemos tenido ocasión de escuchar un remix de ‘Born This Way’ durante el desfile de la marca que tuvo lugar ayer mismo.http://o.aolcdn.com/videoplayer/AOL_PlayerLoader.swfBajo las capas y capas que lleva encima el original, sí podemos intuir que pese a todo, Lady Gaga no ha hecho un giro radical, y que su línea seguirá muy de cerca lo que ya planteó en sus anteriores trabajos y que tan buen resultado le ha dado. Será interesante ver hasta qué punto la electrónica cubrirá esta nueva propuesta, pero salvo filtración, tendremos que esperar al 13 de febrero, fecha de lanzamiento del single y de la ceremonia de los premios Grammy, donde interpretará la canción en directo.Vídeo | AOLVía | MTV

title: YOU GOTTA SEE THIS: “Green Knight (CREEP Remix)” by Memory Tapes
content: YOU GOTTA SEE THIS: “Green Knight (CREEP Remix)” by Memory TapesThe Owl MagBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJul 15, 2011There’s something decidedly…well, creepy about the video for this CREEP remix of Memory Tapes’ “Green Knight.” Maybe it’s the pale girl who stares listlessly, draped in a sheer white dress and covered by her long black hair. title: A remix kultúra árnyoldala
content: A remix kultúra árnyoldalaDoranskyBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 21, 2012Nemrég jelent meg egy érdekes írás arról, hogy az utóbbi húsz évben lelassult a divat fejlődése. Nagyjából ennyi ideje nem léptünk drámaian előre öltözködésben, zenében és egyéb kulturális sajátosságokban a világban, nincs egyértelmű határvonal, amely megkülönböztetné a kilencvenes éveket a 2000-es évektől, miközben a század elején kb. 10 évente fordult ki a kultúra mind zenében, mind öltözködésben.Ennek oka szerintem, hogy az elmúlt 20 év legnagyobb hatású mozgalma a remix kultúra volt. Mivel nagy mennyiségben lett elérhető és felhasználható a 20-ik századi emberiség teljes kultúrtörténete, megszűnt az a fajta izolált alkotási élmény, ami korábban jellemezte a világot.Sok területen könnyebb ma jó minőségű dolgokat gyártani, mint régen, mert a szükséges tudás és alapanyag rendelkezésre áll az interneten és egyéb digitális csatornákon, adatbázisokon keresztül.Azonban ez a korlátlan forrásmennyiség mintha kezdené megmutatni ennek a kultúrának az árnyoldalát is. Sokkal egyszerűbb már meglévő kulturális termékek felfedezésével és keverésével eredeti termékeket kreálni. Ezért van az, hogy képesek divatirányzatok pár hónapra felnőni, majd eltűnni, de valódi karakterük erőteljesen megkérdőjelezhető, gyakran az 1900-as évek divatirányzatainak felhasználásából kevert villanások.Ugyanez a korlátlan forrás mennyiség és remixelési lehetőség eltéríti a kreatív embereket attól, hogy az interneten elérhető digitális források és alapanyagok helyett olyan dolgokat fedezzenek fel, amely kevésbé a remixelés és inkább hasonlít az eredeti kreatív gyártásra.Ez igaz a filmre, a zenére, a táncra és az öltözködésre, magára a webes tervezésre és a mobilra is. Forradalmak nehezen nőnek ki a meglévő anyagok keveréséből, ugyanakkor meg tudjuk vele tömni változatosságra törekvő agyakat, ami úgy néz rövid távon jó, de hosszú távon a nagy változások ellenében hat.
